movie_review_blurb: Death Wish is as original as using AC/DC's "Back in Black" during a training montage and then during the end credits. Which is what it does.
A mid-budget science-fiction effort that borrows so freely from so many other genre favorites, "Automata" barely has an original piece of circuitry in its mainframe.

Easily one of the best documentaries of 2014, "Last Hijack" explores the motivations, circumstances, fears and dreams of a real-life pirate in an admirably objective fashion, while also visualizing his thoughts via gorgeous, lucid-dream-like animation.
As a stand-alone doc, "21 Years" is not worthy of a trip to the theater, but should be more than satisfactory for hardcore Linklater fans and is essential viewing for newcomers.

"Happy Valley" will divide audiences and create heated discussions over the many contradicting reactions given by its subjects. However, there's one point that won't be controversial: It's one of the best documentaries of the year.

Dull and lifeless, "Vice" fails to deliver on the promise of even its lowest ambitions.

"Peace Officer" creates an extremely timely narrative around a volatile issue and manages to not get lost in unproductive hyperbole. It should please fans of real crime procedurals and political junkies alike.

Intelligent, classy and skin-crawling. You won't see a better acting masterclass this year.
Full respect to Carnahan for making the tired crime genre feel fresh, but it would have been more fun without a last-minute attempt to make it mean something.
One of the most impressive movies of the year; taut and compelling.
It suffers from ADD, but there's some terrific stuff in here. Leaving 15 minutes from the end and saving yourself a lumbering coda may improve enjoyment.
A oddball piece of no thrills (or conspicuous talent) filmmaking that's rescued by the charm of those rock survivors, the 'Quo.

It's a story so abhorrent and seemingly hopeless that there may be times you don't want it to go on, but within its tight confines Lenny Abrahamson, with a script by Emma Donoghue, finds warmth and hope.
Dazzlingly clever and hugely funny, it succeeds both as a broadening of the Monsters universe and as a film in its own right.
A Molotov cocktail of laughs and anger, Chi-Raq is a powerful state of a nation address. The result is the most creatively exciting Lee has been in a decade.
Deals with all the usual teenage concerns - dating, family, school - in a way that tries to go beyond genre cliché, with a heroine who is often unlikeable but always believable.
Eastwood's message that no good deed goes unpunished feels misplaced, but for the crash sequences and Hanks' turn it's worthwhile. But for goodness' sake, don't watch it on a plane.
Its plot isn't going to win any prizes for originality, but Nair tells the story with immense warmth and cheer. You can see just about every move coming, but it's making all the right ones.
Perhaps it's fitting that this story about babies has the attention span and grasp of logic of a newborn.
Even if you didn't know what comes next, this story of the first days of the Obamas would still seduce as a sweet, smart romance.
This is a gentler, less confrontational Solondz. It makes you laugh, but probably won't leave you reeling after.
Strong performances and direction make the most of a lightweight tale.
There's not a lot of consequence to this bizarre meeting, or really the film, but as a character study of two men alone at the top, it's both very funny and quietly astute.
Summer 2016 has had a high number of shonky blockbusters, but Gods Of Egypt is the worst of them.
At once empty and impenetrable, this brings to mind a mix of John Carter and Dungeons And Dragons, regrettably in both themes and level of enjoyment.
Just as with Once and Begin Again, Sing Street will make you laugh, cry and leave you humming its songs for days.
It's a tight thriller played out smoothly but tying the viewer in moral knots. A film to think about for days, with little hope of finding a comfortable answer.
Rather than the cynical 'one last grab' of the series, Kung Fu Panda 3 might actually be the best.
Strong subject matter and a superb cast are treated disappointingly with sledgehammer subtlety.
It's a likable mess, although it lacks the memorable lines of the first, making it liable to be enjoyed once and forgotten, rather than revisited for years to come.
Eddie The Eagle turns a long-running joke of British sport into a crowd-pleasing story of inspiration. It's a solid gold winner.
There's something dated about the script, graspingly keen to be edgy but often wearyingly outmoded - are we honestly still treating gay euphemisms as a bottomless well of hilarity?
Everything that comes after the confident, dangerous first half-hour just makes you pine for what could have been as this devolves into ten-a-penny teen-lit sludge.
It feels like both an entire relationship and just the beginning.
movie_title: Paris 05:59: Théo & Hugo (Théo et Hugo dans le même bateau) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a riveting, complex film that asks one simple question: what do you do when there's no right answer?
Even with a clearly signposted ending, it still manages to offer surprises. Nair delights in Uganda, painting a country of many social contrasts and cultures; she embraces possibility, not poverty.
The animation, every frame exquisitely composed, is as stunning as the storytelling.
The animals are cute and Gleeson is extremely game. What keeps Peter from *Paddington*-style delight is a self-conscious need to distance itself from its source material.
A story with all the qualities of a classic LA noir is given a very effective spin by transposing it to politically charged Cairo. It's angry, frustrated and thrilling.
It's the biggest risk of del Toro's career and it could not have paid off more.
It's a classy weepy with some killer dialogue, but Bening is the big sell here. Given one of the juiciest roles of her career, she makes every moment count.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Serkis is clearly sincere in his love for the story, and he draws exceptional performances from Garfield and Claire Foy, but its tone is upbeat to the point of oddness.
Paddington 2 should be prescribed as an antidote to anyone who finds the madness of the modern world a bit wearing. It's probably possible to not absolutely love it, but it's hard to see how.
A film that's at once light, joyful and emotionally devastating, with deeply affecting central performances. A full-hearted romantic masterpiece.
It's a film to see for the performances, which are faultless, but while it's sometimes riveting this play has been awkwardly translated to screen.
It's a film to possibly employ to distract your kids for a few minutes if they've already seen absolutely every other option.
The imagery in this gorgeous Japanese animation is delicate and whimsical, but its plot is increasingly hard and cruel.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As a writing debut for Harris and a feature-directing debut for Napper, this is extremely promising. As a role for Harris, it's a sign that a great British actor may have just hit his moment.
Innately sweet, due to the high number of fluffy animals, but it has the gloopy emotion and silly plotting of a Nicholas Sparks novel. Nicholas Barks, if you will.
To call it the most important movie of the year so far makes it sound possibly rather worthy. That's not true at all. Get Out is a comment on a highly complex situation that's also a total blast.
Stewart shows she's now one of the most interesting actresses of her generation.
All the amusement value of a smack in the mouth.
It's glossy and at times goofily funny, mostly thanks to Johnson's subtle comic skills, but the novelty of this messy relationship is really beginning to wear off.
A sturdy by-the-numbers legal drama that really belongs on the small screen.
Jackie does what the very best biopics should: it makes you view someone you've seen countless times as if you were seeing them anew.
Robert Greene's film follows the actress Kate Lyn Sheil as she prepares to play Chubbuck in a project that's part documentary, part fiction and a bit too much navel-gazing.

It's gorgeous to look at, with its reverse zooms that slowly widen to stunning rural panoramas, its beautiful framing, its delight in decorative detail. You feel you are watching a masterclass in how to recreate the look and feel of the late 18th century.
Magicians as criminals is a marvellous conceit and Louis Leterrier gets a great deal of entertainment out of it, but it can't disguise a weak end with smoke and mirrors.
A very smart take on the stalker movie, which resists easy laughs for harder truths, and might make you think twice the next time you're lining up a photo for social media.
Wonke has the access to make a great documentary, but can't quite find the perfect story focus to put this among the best sporting films.
A few big laughs but weakly drawn characters mean a film that is enjoyable enough in the moment but then quickly forgotten.
The idea has potential but the execution is shrill and flabby and Cassavetes can't land a laugh.
Unthrilling stuff elevated by a capable cast.

There are films to see on huge screens, but this is one that almost cries out for a small cinema, surrounded by total blackness. It's a daring experiment brilliantly executed, with Tom Hardy giving one of the performances of his career.
A flavourless concoction that tries to tap into the storytelling of a Madagascar or Lion King but falls well short of the humour and pathos of either.
Its writer/star has the charm and warmth to keep this muso fairy tale on the tracks and there are entertaining spot-the-rocker cameos galore.
A film that's insane, witty, uneven and almost certain to delight anyone who's ever laid hands on Lego.
In stripping Jack Ryan back to basics it's lost some sophistication, but reinvigorated an action hero who's unlike any other on offer and who absolutely earns his second - or rather fourth - shot.
Not bootiful.
Macdonald's film is a noble stab at bringing Meg Rosoff's YA novel to the screen, which sees Ronan in typically watchable form.
A muddle.
A thin soup of weak jokes and contrived drama.
Confusing and uninspired rather than completely inept, it's still likely to be swiftly struck from the résumés of all involved.
High in gloss if not necessary insight, this is manna for fashion fans but a marginally slighter piece of work than The September Issue.
A film for every age, whether you're an awkward kid, former awkward kid or awkward kid-adjacent. Funny, real and uplifting. A film that reaffirms your belief in the human spirit.
A likeable comedy that uses its greatest asset, its talented, funny cast, to good effect.
The effects have barely aged and the joy is timeless. Take a child who's never seen it and watch their imagination expand before your eyes.
If you're feeling nostalgic, dig out some copies of the original cartoon instead.

Often witty and provocative, if occasionally a little heavy on its feet, this will have men of a certain age nodding sagely.
If this tiresome yarn is the 'true' story of one of Disney's most popular villains then, please, give us colourful lies and happy ignorance.

movie_review_blurb: If you enjoy Gondry's brand of homemade art direction then there's plenty to delight early on, but it's all wallpaper.

It's a decent diversion.
I left feeling a bit uncomfortable, but the fact that Shepard gets away with it at all is a testament to his talent.

Smith, in other words, does exactly what you'd expect the hero of a bloody, trashy, volcanically depraved action movie to do. He just does it a little bit...more so, and that's the rollicking good joke of Shoot 'Em Up
It's the first Hollywood Iraq movie to remind me of a Vietnam film like Coming Home, and it does more than disturb. It scalds, moves, and heals.
A plodding and highly questionable history lesson.
Lurid, fascinating, sickening, and eye-opening.
A spooky, moving doc that chronicles the first solo attempt to circle the world by boat.

In the Shadow of the Moon finds new resonance in the moment when America redefined progress -- but also when it heeded the siren song of a world so desolate it reminded you what a paradise ours truly is.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's the kind of comedy that finds Asian people hi-lar-ious because they're...Asian. (Are you laughing yet?)
You'll go ''Huh?'' but you won't feel cheated.
A sturdy and enjoyable remake of the 1957 minor classic.
Atkinson's goofball grotesquerie never lets up.
It would be nice to see a sharp, funny, penetrating satire of the new, kicked-up culture of empty media fame, but Tom DiCillo's scattershot buddy movie Delirious isn't it.

If you're going to imply that a French couple being terrorized in a remote Romanian mansion adds up to something more than an arbitrary (and rather repetitive) don't-go-in-the-basement thriller, then you'd better deliver the goods.
The Invasion gets you rooting for the aliens to be defeated, but the film's soul feels as if it had already been snatched.

Bay, at heart, isn't a fantasist; he's a literal-minded maestro of demolition. But then, that serves Transformers well during its climax, a spectacular clash of the heavy metal titans, and a primal reminder of why boys love their toys.
Spider-Man 3 is product, but it's a machine that tickles your eyes.
[A] precious, inert dud of a hitmen-are-people-too comedy.
You could wander into this poetic documentary willing to be sympathetic toward its subject -- men who have sex with horses -- and still find Zoo cryptic and borderline bogus.
Waitress is a wee romantic charmer, a delectable Dixie screwball romp that never loses its spry sense of discovery.

When critics complain about the dumbing down of movies into franchise popcorn, what we're really doing is yearning for a terrifically engrossing, tethered-to-the-real-world drama like Michael Clayton.
This lacerating drama from writer-director Hilary Brougher shines a piercing light onto some of the hidden terrors of women, especially in an era when abstinence can shade into ignorance.
In the Land of Women combines hugs and ''pain'' and dialogue so fakey-cute it makes your ears hurt.
It may be obvious that Fracture is working on us, playing us, but that's its pleasure. It makes overwrought manipulation seem more than a basic instinct.
Vacancy is a schlock surprise: a no-frills motel-hell slasher film -- with a bit of soul.
Leto and Hayek make their erotic psychohistrionics fun, and John Travolta and James Gandolfini, as cops, work up a dour camaraderie.

The intoxicating documentary Jack Smith and the Destruction of Atlantis, directed by Mary Jordan, is a love poem to the New York City of the '50s and '60s, when Smith, the visionary of camp, more or less invented performance art.
movie_title: Jack Smith and the Destruction of Atlantis (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Disturbia, unlike Hitchcock's masterpiece of urban-courtyard fishbowl voyeurism, is a Rear Window that never bothers to peer into more than one window.
It summons the most crackerjack pop charge of any movie with Tarantino's name on it since Pulp Fiction.
No belief on earth can rescue Swank from a film that's a chain of disaster chintz masquerading as a sermon.
First Snow is essentially a short story with a metaphysical twist, but Pearce puts his fears more up front than any actor I can think of. He keeps you poked and prodded with anxiety.
Joseph Gordon-Levitt, as a fellow who has suffered serious head trauma, comes up with such a moody Method assemblage of twitches, tics, and guilty Memento mannerisms that he's not much fun to watch.
It's hard not to grin and admit that, yes, this is almost an art form.
Blades of Glory has funny moves even when its characters can barely move, but the film seldom gets past its one basic laugh: that a real man figure-skating is a contradiction in terms.
The film reveals, rather delectably, how potent the power of suggestion can be in a world gone madly groupie.
The ultimate crime of this paranoid enemy-of-the-state pulp, directed with more style than brains by Antoine Fuqua, is how dull it is.
Pride doesn't have much surprise, but it's a formula picture of genuine feeling, with Terrence Howard proving once again that he wouldn't know how to keep it less than real.
Reality TV often consists of greasy hybrids -- it's The Osbournes meets Andrew Dice Clay! -- and this exposé of how the reality sausage gets made, is itself less than pure.
movie_title: American Cannibal: The Road to Reality (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Maxed Out, while occasionally muddled in its financial details, presents a more-accurate-than-not vision of a nation that is starting to look like a candidate for rehab, on both an individual and a national level, for its addiction to debt.

The ferocity of [director Ken] Loach's moral wrath carries the movie, makes it ignite on screen -- at least, until he tries to dramatize the fatal split of Ireland through Damien and Teddy, the brothers in arms.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The movie, for all its huffing and puffing, explores very little, even if some of it is sexy in a Howard Stern-meets-9 1/2 Weeks way.
They should have called this Perturbia.
A stunt masquerading as a statement.
Anthology films usually work better in theory than execution, but this feature parade of shorts is a blithe, worldly, and enchanting exception.
Lohan hits a true note of spiteful princess narcissism. Unfortunately, it's the only note the film allows her to play.
Ratatouille has the Pixar technical magic without, somehow, the full Pixar flavor. It's Brad Bird's genial dessert, not so much incredible as merely sweetly edible.
Eli Roth's Hostel: Part II is an authentic real-world creep show -- better, if anything, than its predecessor.
[A] shimmeringly decadent and fascinating portrait of the West Coast jazz legend Chet Baker.
12:08 East of Bucharest is a shrewdly built comedy, but the characters are broad-verging-on-cheap unholy hick fools.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a tale that reduces angst, not to mention love, to a generational tic.
Reassuringly old-school gothic.
[Director] Jaglom's scruffy style doesn't carry it through. He puts enough toxic insincerity on screen to singe, though.
Director Keven McAlester thinks he's making Crumb, but he doesn't give you enough of [Roky] Erickson in his glory. You're Gonna Miss Me has the taint of exploitation.
Hurtling and impassioned, driven by some of the greatest popular music ever recorded, this wildly overripe and unkempt biopic is a true experience.
[A] delectably elaborate and savory soufflé of a mother-of-all-scams sequel.
Mr. Brooks begins promisingly, but it grows steadily more preposterous as it goes along, becoming the first feel-good serial-killer movie.
A spectacularly turbulent portrait of the chaos and bloodshed that have come to define Haiti.
Years after Federal Hill (1994), director Michael Corrente is still doing low-budget Mean Streets knockoffs.
It's a freak show of a fairy tale, rendered by a filmmaker who knows how to pierce tabloid reality right in its anguished, bloody heart.
This satire of empty-suit capitalism has scalding moments, but most of it suggests Being There meets The Office gibberized into theater of the absurd.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Angel-A shows how director Luc Besson can be French in a way that even the French might despise.

Six Days makes the potent case that in taking over all of Jerusalem, Israel turned its greatest military triumph into a Pyrrhic victory. A debatable thesis? Yes, but also one that asks the price of certainty.
I Have Never Forgotten You salutes this bureaucratic detective as the man who first insisted that war crimes are sins that won't die unless they are dragged into the open.
movie_title: I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life And Legacy Of Simon Wiesenthal (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Steel City could have used more rhythmic drive, but if [Brian] Jun keeps weaving together characters this compelling, he could be a major film artist in the making.
Just about every character in At World's End comes with his or her own agenda, and the movie grows top-heavy as we attempt to keep track of who's trying to accomplish what.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The chintzy characters, hair-raising deaths, and one spectacular rocket-launcher joke aren't enough to give Hostel a run for its blood, but they will keep the desensitized occupied.
The faux espionage plot, with its winks at terrorism, is really just a convoluted plea for the relevance of precious indie artistes (i.e., Hal Hartley).
The movie swoons, and you will too.
The Wendell Baker Story just feels like an attempt to rebottle the postmodern fizz of Wes Anderson's Bottle Rocket. I wish instead they'd put a stopper in it.
Why is Gracie as processed as an after-school special? You miss the knockabout edge of Bend It Like Beckham -- though the ending, in its Pavlovian sports-flick way, pumps you up.
Control goes past the clichés of punk rock-god gloom to offer a snapshot of alienation that's shockingly humane.

Walk Hard isn't merciless (except for maybe one wicked sequence with the Beatles), and that's because it so loves what it's sending up: the pleasure, ego, and sheer exhaustion of what happens behind the music.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film completely misses what should have been its real target -- the filming of Game of Death, a martial-arts campfest worthy of Edward D. Wood Jr.
There are a few lively bits, and one joke with an edge: a slap at Stephen Hawking and his computer-drone voice. Mostly, though, this is super-lame.
My Blueberry Nights hints that buried in Wong's spicy odd noodlings may be an even better conventional filmmaker.
What it captures is a band that has figured out the best way to endure -- by becoming eternal.
It's obvious that The Grand's director, Zak Penn, set out to make the Best in Show of high-stakes poker, but to raise the ante, he piles up the absurdities and zany backstories.
Director David Schwimmer bloats this slapdash concept into dim, witless overkill.
21 is built around some standard-issue plot mechanics, but it's still a clever and novel card-sharp thriller.
For those few soul-freezing moments, you get a glimpse of the great actor Leonardo DiCaprio is going to be.
This one is just murk.

A muckraking documentary of vast shuddery intrigue, makes a disquieting case that Russia hasn't just slipped back to its old oligarchic ways -- but that, in fact, it's a more repressive, corroded place than it was in the age of the Soviet Union.
movie_title: Bunt. Delo Litvinenko (Poisoned by Polonium: The Litvinenko File) (Rebellion: The Litvinenko Case) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Before you can say, 'Wow, that sounds boring,' director Patricia Riggen has smuggled us, with no-bull authority, into the rituals, jokes, and survival games of a culture of half-existence: people who live in two places and nowhere at all.
Bleak, brilliant, and unsparing: a full-scale vision of the madness that is tearing up the black inner city.

If you had programmed a computer to come up with a movie that is nothing but a string of the deadliest indie-film situations and moods, you'd have Sleepwalking, a soporific dud, which should have been tossed out of Sundance.
Frownland, Ronald Bronstein's startling comedy, is like a mumblecore Eraserhead directed by John Cassavetes.
Paranoid Park has the slightly glum insularity of minimalist fiction, but it's the first of Van Sant's blitzed-generation films in which a young man wakes up instead of shutting down.
Can a movie be gripping and repellent at the same time?
[Sheridan] works with such piercing fervor and intelligence that In the Name of the Father just about transcends its tidy moral design.
movie_title: In the Name of the Father (1993)

movie_review_blurb: What could possibly have possessed Stephen Chow, the mad scientist of slapstick chopsocky who made Kung Fu Hustle, to follow up that psychedelic pinwheel of a movie by entangling himself in CJ7?
Snow Angels is such a fascinating smorgasbord of flawed behavior that it exerts the voyeuristic pull of a first-rate small-town soap opera.

Watching The Bank Job, you buy the heist, and you also buy the entertaining layer cake of British society -- the black radicals, smut lords, and MI5 agents who treat cops like janitors, all fighting for their piece of the action.
The Lion King, more than any of the recent wave of Disney animated features, has the resonance to stand not just as a terrific cartoon but as an emotionally pungent movie.
City of Men has the electrically oversaturated style of reality that made City of God such a searing vision of teenage criminal life in the slums of Rio de Janeiro.
Is there anything more dull than an ineptly cynical fairy tale?
Chicago 10 is well worth seeing, if only because a good half of the film is devoted to extraordinary footage of the four days of rage that spawned the trial.

The Ruins is lumpish, static, and obvious. It's a gringos-go-home cautionary fright flick done in the spirit of a cheap '50s horror movie, except that it leaves you longing for the competence of grade-Z studio-system trash.
Bad Lieutenant is finally a pulp parable of sin, addiction, and redemption, a movie that, like its subversive hero, revels in the pleasure -- and danger -- of going too far.

The fun of Smart People, which was written by Mark Jude Poirier and directed by Noam Murro, is seeing Quaid bite, with darkly funny and misanthropic gusto, into the acrid soul of a man whose life has curdled.

The structure is in place -- the latticework of corruption -- only there are so many scurrilous men pulling strings that we might be watching a parade of nasty puppets, with Keanu as the chief wooden devil doll.
Whatever your persuasion, you'll walk out enriched.
It's genuine sick fun, and there isn't a boring moment in it.
movie_title: Poultrygeist: Night of the Chicken Dead (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A good documentary will take you places you didn't plan to go, but I didn't really expect that from Bigger, Stronger, Faster, an incisive and compulsively watchable look at America's love affair with steroids.
A stirring drama of frayed nationality and hungry connection.
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It takes skill -- a certain sly, even perverse nimbleness of craft -- to make an homage to schlock movies that treats them as works of art. Viva, written and directed by its star, Anna Biller, could just about be the third featurette in Grindhouse.
Dark, funny, paranoid, arbitrary, humming with tamped-down eroticism and in love with all things weird: That's the good news.
A fierce and somber battle epic.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is a liberal plea without liberation.
The premise is out of '70s porn, and so is the overbroad satire and almost total lack of conviction.
Ashton Kutcher and Cameron Diaz hate on each other with dynamite verve in What Happens in Vegas.
There are plenty of soulless movies around. What's special about Days of Thunder is that it works overtime trying to convince you it's not one of them.
A classy romantic cocktail distinguished by its tart yet breezy bite.
The movie has a pleasing daftness.

Made of Honor is a nice cookie-cutter comedy, no more and no less, but Dempsey, with his relaxed charm, and Monaghan, with her soft and peachy sensual spark, rise to the challenge of making friendship look like the wellspring of true love.

The fun of Iron Man, a Marvel adaptation in which a routine arc has been burnished with great elegance and skill, is the way that it heals the split, soldering the two halves of its hero into a single organically driven figure.
A fitfully funny if somewhat less excellent sequel.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Dumb and Dumber, which features Carrey and Jeff Daniels as nitwits traveling cross-country, is a frayed string of gags posing as a movie. Carrey, though, does literal-minded doofdom with peerless enthusiasm.
The most chilling thing about the film is how hard it is to completely separate yourself from those guilty U.S. soldiers. Now who in the world would want to go see that?

In his first film since Super Size Me, Spurlock tells you virtually nothing you didn't already know -- and, what's more, he does it with catchy videogame graphics and faux-naive man-on-the-street interviews that make Michael Moore look like Chet Huntley.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: One hardly needs to have grown up Italian in the '60s to feel a pang of nostalgia watching My Brother Is an Only Child, Daniele Luchetti's tale of small-town brothers.
movie_title: Mio Fratello è Figlio Unico (My Brother Is an Only Child) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: [A] one-joke Caddyshack for the blitzed and jaded.
It's saying Roberts' character becomes a better person when she lands a rich guy and learns to cry at the opera.
Mangold certainly knew what he was doing when he cast Keitel and De Niro.
Chapter 27 is far from flawless, but Leto disappears inside this angry, mouth-breathing psycho geek with a conviction that had me hanging on his every delusion.
After Gummo and Julien Donkey-Boy, the director Harmony Korine evinces a kind of integrity -- he tries never to entertain, and lo, he succeeds.

As long as it's dissecting the six or seven passages in the Bible that ostensibly disparage homosexuality, this documentary ode to tolerance takes a shrewd look at how speciously selective and ahistorical the church condemnation of gays really is.
movie_title: For the Bible Tells Me So (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Rarely has the gulf between relevance of subject matter and ineptitude of execution been greater than it is in Ezra.
The gorgeous floorboards creak -- loudly -- in the veteran French director Jacques Rivette's fascinating drawing-room war of the sexes, The Duchess of Langeais.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A stirring, revelatory film, which captures Seeger as the media-age Johnny Appleseed of folk.
movie_title: Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A dawdling, myopic drama.
The tiny scale and armchair talkiness mark the movie as a bit of a folly, an act of idealistic hubris in today's commercial marketplace, yet that's its (minor) fascination too.
Southland Tales has a mood unlike anything I've seen: dread that morphs into kitsch and then back again. It's a film that tried my patience, and one I couldn't shake off.

The reports of torture porn's demise may have been greatly exaggerated, but this fourth entry in the mutilate-yourself-or-die series joins what may be the worst genre of the decade: the lamely ''sympathetic'' serial-killer backstory.
This beautiful and urgent eco-doc takes a bite out of the shark mythology made indelible by Jaws.
There are wounding tales of rape and murder, of parents watching their children massacred, in this clear-eyed documentary account of the genocide in Darfur.
The Future Is Unwritten captures the Joe Strummer who, in the late 1970s, just about firebombed the rock establishment with his fury.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film is nutty, ecological, antically funny, and moving, all at the same time.
American Gangster is meticulous and detailed, a drug-world epic that holds you from moment to moment, immersing you in the intricate and sleazy logistics of crime.
It's becoming a bit tiresome watching Kevin Bacon suffer, and he isn't done any favors by this thudding weeper.
This behind-the-scenes portrait of David Lynch, shot over the two years it took him to piece together Inland Empire, is as skewed, prismatic, and free of fluff as the man himself.
Director Jonathan Demme creates a gripping meditation on the very hot-button-ness of the Israeli-Palestinian question.
Dan in Real Life is a comedy of faith that, in its wised-up feel-good way, restores yours.
Proof that Sidney Lumet's talent is, in every sense, timeless.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Aaron Woolf's we-are-what-we-eat documentary King Corn is a lively introduction to the corn industrial complex.

Amid the shout-downs over adultery, male power, and the agony of coping with a child's death, one performance glistens -- Jill Scott's as the sad, heavyset Sheila, who locates the faith that's the source of love.
30 Days of Night is relentless, but it's also relentlessly one-note.

Rendition makes the case that torture, whatever name it goes under, is indefensible, yet one can agree with that view entirely and still feel that the movie is just a borderline exploitation of what anyone who reads the papers already knows.
Die-hard greenies may find this as unsettling as it's meant to be. For everyone else, it's closer to an atmospheric act of recycling.
[A] hit-or-miss, not-as-bad-as-you've-heard remake of the 1972 minor classic.
It's like Deathtrap crossed with Cribs as staged by Stanley Kubrick.
Gray is a far better director than he is a writer. He's got the talent to make great movies. He just needs to stop trying to.

Lagerfeld Confidential, while an undisciplined piece of filmmaking, offers a rare glimpse into the soul of the fashion world, with Lagerfeld, as he admits, surviving through his philosophical fixation on The New: life as the proverbial next season.
Beowulf is a solemnly gorgeous, at times borderline stolid piece of Tolkien-with-a-joystick mythology.
The toys all have prankish lives of their own -- which could have been fun, in a Harry Potter meets Flubber sort of way, except that when you actually see the playthings, they don't look fun at all.

The singular haunting beauty of I'm Not There, Todd Haynes' thrilling deep-vision meditation on the music and many lives of Bob Dylan, is that obsession isn't just its fuel -- it's the movie's spirit and subject, its driving force.

The director, Pete Travis, is a pulse-pounding technological showman whose high-strung, quick-cut style might be described as JFK meets Paul Greengrass meets Jerry Bruckheimer. That said, it's not the plot that thickens -- it's the pulp.
There's no real behavior, just endless movement brought off with empty crackerjack skill.
As horror, Diary of the Dead delivers the gross-out goods, but only the gullible will confuse these ritualized shock-videogame tactics with something relevant.
As Jimmy, the teen sap who falls hard for Suzanne, Joaquin Phoenix is dead-eyed yet touchingly vulnerable -- a mush-mouthed angel.
Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show has a loosey-goosey, what-the-hell spirit that's easy and fun to hook into.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Let's just say that enjoyment, even trashy enjoyment, is not to be sneered at. Boredom, on the other hand, is -- and that's the real crime committed by the dead-in-the-water Fool's Gold.
The Farrelly brothers could burp out a movie funnier than The Hottie & the Nottie, a farce of corrupt stereotypes that's never more grotesque than when it pretends to be more than skin-deep.
Backdraft has some of the raw filmmaking excitement that has been missing from Howard's recent work.
The 3-D visuals envelop you, majestically, and that effect fuses with the band's surround-sound rapture to create a full-scale sensory high. U2 3D makes you feel stoned on movies.
Rock & roll may never die, but you know it's been eaten by the consumer culture when you see Hannah Montana & Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert.
movie_title: Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This tale of two brothers wrenched apart when they act badly is really a testament to its stars, who in this film act very well, and with visible joy. They make working for Woody Allen into a promise fulfilled.
This Look Ma, no hands! And no head either! horror film makes a Mixmaster stew out of Poltergeist, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, Re-Animator, They Came From Within, and Shaun of the Dead.

Mad Money, a sisters-in-greed heist comedy that's like Fun With Dick and Jane crossed with Set It Off, may be a formula flick, but as directed by Callie Khouri, it gives you a good, infectious dose of its heroines' money fe
It's fun, for two minutes, to see Nicholson and Freeman jumping out of a plane, but once they've gotten tattoos and raced vintage cars, the movie is already scraping the bottom of the bucket.

Billy the Kid, a movie that's as interesting as it is dewy-eyed, may be the rare snapshot of an adolescent 'outcast' who is really the guy made for fame, with a built-in radar for how to present himself in front of the camera.
...The Great Debaters soars with words and feeling.
...The film is well-done, a case of suspenseful competence trumping questionable relevance.
Charlie Wilson's War is a journalistic satire of realpolitik in which our jerry-rigged alliances, which looked strategic at the time, end up biting the U.S. in unforeseen ways.
The movie is one soporific, depressed, deadeningly vague scene after another.
For two hours and 42 minutes, Into Great Silence offers painterly images of an existence that is, almost literally, too reverent for words.
A lovely comedy of death and rebirth.

The movie, a heady thicket of political intrigue and double crosses, is slower, talkier, and more prosaic than the first two films, and its narrative seams sometimes show. And yet it's more than the sum of its mazelike convolutions.
The Golden Compass is a snowbound mystical-whizbang kiddie ride that hovers somewhere between the loopy and the lugubrious.
An enjoyable pop projection of post-9/11 anxiety. That said, it also makes you nostalgic for the days when irresponsible action movies didn't have to deal with it.

It's white-lace porn for girls of every age, and the way that it revels in that get-me-to-the-altar mood, to the point of making anyone who isn't getting married feel like a loser, is the picture's key selling point.
The filmmaker, Cam Archer, seems to be trying for a mood of hazy self-pity, which he achieves just enough to make you wish he'd get over it.
Eat up, chick-flickaholics! Even if you know it's not good for you.
Graham makes the coming-out dithering bearable, but not before she has jumped through hoops of contrivance.
To watch Hard Candy is, at moments, to be very afraid, but the scariest thing about it is the fury of Page's talent.

Antonio Banderas is a charming and talented man, but in Take the Lead he lays on the old-world panache so thick -- the accent, the flowery courtliness, the romance of romance -- that he comes off like Dracula's metrosexual cousin.
About all that unifies the movie is its inclination to turn little people's dreams into limply 'affectionate' camp.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: For all its game invention, is less Pulp Fiction than an Elmore Leonard knockoff crossed with Deathtrap: a thriller that holds less interest -- and less water -- the more it reveals about what's actually going on.
Basic Instinct 2 isn't bad, exactly, but it lacks the entertaining vulgarity of the first film.
The Devil and Daniel Johnston is a fascinating and lovingly crafted musical documentary that nevertheless misunderstands its own subject.
Unlike the great foreign films of old, L'Enfant makes catharsis look easy.
The Zodiac has been made with the dunderheaded flatness of bad '70s TV.
It never truly reveals who Brian Jones was before he fell apart. His indulgence, and his demise, play out in a void.
If Take My Eyes explored how a woman could still feel for a man who abused her, it might have gripped us with its difficult truths.
movie_title: Te doy mis ojos (Take My Eyes) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Bynes, with her chipmunk cheeks and goggly eyes, comes off more like some bizarre third sex -- Davy Jones after an infusion of estrogen.
What gives it a vital, touching dimension is that Shepard, as actor and writer, depicts Howard's burnout from a hard-bitten inside knowledge of celebrity's privileges and traps.
V for Vendetta has a playful-demon vitality, but it's designed to let political adolescents of every age congratulate themselves. It's rage against the machine by the machine.
Yes, folks, it's a message movie.
It's lifeless kitsch.
Argento's entire performance is an act of exhibitionism, and so is the movie, which would have done well to drop that cynical and verbose title and substitute something catchier.
movie_title: The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Let's not sell Tyler Perry short. As the vinegar-witted Madea, he's a drag performer of testy charm, but in his overlit patchwork way he's also making the most primal women's pictures since Joan Crawford flexed her shoulder pads.
Dave Chappelle's Block Party is perhaps the first concert movie since Stop Making Sense to give you a blissful buzz.
What's eye-opening, as well as depressing, is that the film reveals how even the politics of a nation's life and death can now be reduced to a technocratic shell game.
Unknown White Male is framed as a look at the mystery of identity, but there's a bizarre neutrality to the movie.
You have to be hungry for comedy that's salty and loud, that hits your palate with all the delicacy of hot grease. If you're in that mood, a handful of these jokes will likely be just what you crave.

The actors are terrific, especially Weaving, who plays bottoming out as a tragedy spiked with gallows humor, and Blanchett, who digs deep into the booby-trapped nature of recovery. The revelation, however, is Rowan Woods, a major filmmaker in the making.

The complication in Freedomland arises out of Brenda's hysteria, which is so extreme that we doubt her story even before we've bought into it, and from the movie's dogged, booby-trapped demonstration of the sins of racism.
Earnest to the point of dullness.
The three losers play a series of Little League teams, snatching victory from the jaws of slapstick humiliation.
A comedy of high freakishness that invites us to climb deep into the mystique of Bettie Page's image, her phenomenon.
You could dismiss this swankily shot Latin American trifle as an upscale soap opera, but that would be an insult to soap operas.
I felt like I was seeing The Da Vinci Code with slightly shadier priests.
