She's a teller of hilarious gutbucket truths as surely as Lenny Bruce and Richard Pryor ever were. Yet while they were consumed by their demons, Rivers is just the opposite. Letting her demons run wild is what saves her, every day.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Fans will gorge on this deft, year-by-year portrait of the ultimate enduring cult band. And even a skeptic may come away with an affection for the intricate labor of Rush's skewed-time-signature epics.
The Karate Kid is fun, and believable, on the most important level: It convinces us that Jaden Smith has what it takes to fight his way to the top.
It has a rambly, realistic tone, with one orgiastic mishap spilling into the next, and that tone keeps much of the action popping with surprise.
The pulp is served thick, with so much sincerely purple passion it's disarming.

I'm all for a new take on an old story. But Scott and his screenwriter, Brian Helgeland, work so mightily to turn Robin   into a stolidly noble, pre-notorious version of himself that they forget to make him at all magical. Rousing. A hero of the gle
It's a kitchen sink full of dirty dishes that don't match.
I don't know about you, but the moment I hear the word lobbyist, my brain glazes over. Casino Jack and the United States of Money woke my brain, and my outrage, right up.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Crying, peeing, grinning, crawling (there's a brief crawling montage -- the one such gimmick), the babies in Babies offer moments to cherish. Frankly, though, the film itself is kind of slack.
Much of the film's ''entertainment value'' rests on the sadistically outlandish performance of Dieter Laser, who's like Boris Karloff starring in a movie by Rainer Werner Fassbinder.

There's not a whole lot to Cop Out besides watching Kevin Smith pretend, with a crudeness that is simply boring, that he's an action director making a comic thriller about cops versus a Mexican drug gang (yawn).
The movie does have a payoff, though. And it works, shiveringly well.
Like an Israeli Amores Perros crossed with City of God.
Bad Lieutenant doesn't go where you expect, but it has a stubborn, trippy logic.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Messenger honors those who fought and died in Iraq by acting out, with an anguished handheld immediacy, how large each of those sacrifices really is.
The actors, all great camera subjects, help give director Adam Salky's overly pat movie a trace of confessional conviction.
Kelly has talent, but for his next movie, he might try coming down to earth and forgetting about the people who control the lightning.
To Wes Anderson: More, please!

Schindler's List is a film whose meanings are to be found less in its uplifting outline than in its harrowing flow of images -- images of fear, hope, horror, compassion, degradation, chaos, and death.
Margot Benacerraf's starkly beautiful 1959 documentary Araya is the rare film whose austere stylistic impersonality is a key aspect of its elemental power.
Spielberg's peerless twin gift has always been for making the fantastic seem real (Close Encounters, E.T., the Indiana Jones trilogy) and the real fantastic (Jaws).

Precious captures how a lost girl rouses herself from the dead, and Daniels shows unflinching courage as a filmmaker by going this deep into the pathologies that may still linger in the closets of some impoverished inner-city lives.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Disney's A Christmas Carol is a marvelous and touching yuletide toy of a movie, and the miracle is that it goes right back to the gilded Victorian spirit of those black-and-white films of yore.
The Men Who Stare at Goats is a magical-realist sitcom war farce that ends up being about nothing but its own slovenly smugness.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Too often, The Fourth Kind makes the paranormal look disappointingly normal.
It's not a pretty picture, but it is not a naive one either. The grippingly articulate Ruppert is like Noam Chomsky as a wry pundit of doom.
Hal Holbrook was born to play sly, cantankerous rascals.
Would those concerts have returned him to his magical pedestal? We'll never know the answer, of course. But watching this movie, at least we get a feel of it.
The Saw series long ago cannibalized its cleverest bloodbath gimmicks, but now it's figured out a new way to torture us: by taking a barb-wire stab at political relevance.
Astro Boy is a marvelously designed piece of cartoon kinetics, with the pleasing soft colors and rounded-metal tactility of an atomic-age daydream.
The impotent folly of Antichrist is that von Trier has made it his mission to shock the bourgeoisie in an era when they can no longer be shocked.
[Thurman is] quite funny, but her performance is at once winning and overstated.

The trouble with the movie, apart from its rather monotonous dourness of tone, is that everyone in the family... comes off as tougher, smarter, and quicker on the draw than the stepfather who's supposed to be outfoxing them.

Monaghan, so good in Gone Baby Gone, mopes self-consciously through the role of Diane, a loner who finds her heart when she's thrown together with her estranged 11-year-old son (Jimmy Bennett), whom she takes on the road. Yes, it's one of those movies.
It's a David-and-Goliath tale, full of anger and disturbing accusation, but it's also inspiring.
What I mostly noticed is how quickly I've grown tired of Butler's mush-mouthed bravura, and also how much I hope that Foxx, who looks bored, holds his slumming down to this one film.
What The Blind Side offers is a kind of liberal Hollywood version of conservative values: all rock-solid valor, all the time.
The movie is at once intimate and (in its softhearted way) preachy.
The Road, for all its vivid desolation, remains a curiously unmoving experience.

Leading the defense in the 1969-70 trial of the Chicago Seven, William Kunstler became a radical and a celebrity, and this vivid documentary captures how those two facets of his life worked together in morally urgent and contradictory ways.
The Wolfman, hokey and uneven though it is, [has] the kind of authentic emotional hook that too many horror movies today don't have.
Terminator 2 is a state-of-the-art action movie, all right: It gets you thinking that the most reasonable thing might just have been to blow everyone away.
Boogie Nights, an epic tale of porn, pleasure, and excess, offers a purer hit of exhilaration than any movie this year.
From Paris With Love is a ''fun trash'' movie that's more trash than fun.
Scorsese has taken the harsh mystery out of Tibetan Buddhism, and out of its oppression, too.
As compressed and updated by screenwriters William Monahan and Andrew Bovell, it's just a conventional, divertingly propulsive, borderline boilerplate corporate-high-jinks thriller.

[Stone] seems to be trying to enter a more passionate movie, where a neurotic gold digger could at least have a good time. By the end of Casino, for all its craftsmanly bravura, you may want to join her.
Darwin turned the world upside down, but there was more drama seeing Greg Kinnear play the inventor of the intermittent windshield wiper in Flash of Genius.
Téchiné has made a half-captivating, half-baffling tease of a movie in which one woman's destructive whim has the effect of making anti-Semitism look like a myth.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This slyly transcendental documentary consists of long, mostly wordless takes of sheep, cowboys, and the divine Montana mountains they wander through for 200 miles.
It's all very sincere, but watching a dweebish depressive learn that Life Is Good is a lesson of diminishing returns.
The movie has all the coherence of a bad acid flashback.
A ponderous dystopian bummer that might be described as The Road Warrior without car chases, or The Road without humanity.

If the young Ann-Margret had been allowed to wiggle her brain as much as her bod, she might have come off something like Amy Adams. Is there an actress today who can suffuse a single scene with so many infectious mood swings?
Set in a German village on the eve of World War I, The White Ribbon treats a dozen characters so coldly they could be rats in a maze.
Sherlock Holmes, while a diverting enough night out, is both fun and numb, enjoyable and exhausting. It's a case of more adding up to less.
Will kids eat up this cutely fractious claptrap? Of course they will. They'll eat up whatever you put in front of them. But that doesn't make The Squeakquel good for them.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As visual spectacle, Avatar is indelible, but as a movie it all but evaporates as you watch it.

The film's speechifying is at times overexplicit, yet Freeman lets the words breathe, and Damon, as the cautious Afrikaner brought to a higher place by Mandela's authority, acts with a   coolly impassive fervor.
Marshall's staging lacks the thrilling unity he brought to Chicago. The numbers, while lively, remain cluttered and stage-bound.
This is the first movie directed by Tom Ford, the former fashion designer, and he proves a born filmmaker with a rapturous eye.

Director Jean-Marc Vallée's images have a creamy stateliness, but this is no gilded   princess fantasy -- it's the story of a budding ruler who learns to control her surroundings, and Blunt makes that journey at once authentic and relevant.
Up in the Air is light and dark, hilarious and tragic, romantic and real. It's everything that Hollywood has forgotten how to do; we're blessed that Jason Reitman has remembered.

Brothers isn't badly acted, but as directed by the increasingly impersonal Jim Sheridan, it's lumbering and heavy-handed, a film that piles on overwrought dramatic twists until it begins to creak under the weight of its presumed significance.
It's like Children of Men with exploding-plasma shock effects. The best thing you can say about the movie is that it pours some very old blood into a new plastic bottle.
An aspiring cult film that would rather be cute than dangerous.
Every time the film makes you chuckle, you may also feel it's zapped you with a neuralizer.
A piece of blandly enthusiastic, B-movie pulp.
Coppola is a true filmmaker, and in Somewhere she pierces the Hollywood bubble from the inside.
Blue Valentine wrenches us with its painful and tender understanding of how people with even this tattered a connection can lunge for love as if it were air.

As long as it's engaged in light-hurling bouts of force, or motorcycle chases through a landscape so ominously enveloping it looks like Blade Runner after gentrification, TRON: Legacy is a catchy popcorn pleasure.
You go into a movie like The Tourist hoping for a feast of personality from the stars. What you get, in this case, is a waxworks version of chemistry.
There's a certain predictability to The Fighter, yet that's part of the appeal of the fight genre. This one, as thoughtful as it is rousing, scores a TKO.
The canniest thing about it is that it carves shrewd and lively dramatic arcs out of souls who are too damaged to feel their own feelings.
You can't take it too seriously, but you can't tear your eyes away from it, either.
A shrewd, timely, and terrifically engrossing drama of white-collar reckoning that marks the feature directorial debut of writer-producer John Wells.
Depardieu and Marie Bunel (as Bellamy's wife) have a terrific interplay, but Chabrol's sharp direction can't quite rescue his fuzzy script.
Ford is still a magnetic hunk of gray-granite movie star, and in Morning Glory, he finds a way to trick up his deadly somber, shifting-quicksand delivery into a shrewd and amusing acting style.
Carrey suggests an escaped mental patient impersonating a game-show host.
Deepens the saga of New York's former governor and attorney general into the paradoxical morality play it really was.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Fair Game gets you riled up all over again at a deeply unpatriotic abuse of power.
Megamind is less a satire of dastardly deeds than a nimbly spectacular comedy of ego.
Saw 3D is sicko-exploitative, viscera-spewing trash, but at least it has a lean and mean pace and focus, and it isn't clotted with backstory.
127 Hours offers a daunting challenge to a filmmaker: How do you rivet an audience when your protagonist can't even move? The answer is that there's an awesome freedom to Danny Boyle's filmmaking.

The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest is mostly an epic rehash of the tale Larsson has already told, and that makes it, at two hours and 28 minutes, the first movie in the series that never catches fire.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Even when nothing is happening, the often dead-silent shots tend to grow scarier the more you look at them.
More than ever, Johnny Knoxville and his boys belong to a very elite club of idiocy.
Director Gaspar Noé proved a shock poet in Irreversible. In Enter the Void, he's a shockingly tedious show-off.
Arnold Schwarzenegger appears as the rare politician who supports reform in this timely exposé of how our democracy has slipped off its tracks.
Olivier Assayas' three-part drama about Carlos the Jackal, the Venezuelan-born radical-Marxist terrorist of the '70s and '80s, is a rivetingly journalistic account of a scoundrel's rise and fall.
It's a minimalist Sideways, not so much mumblecore as talkycore.
The film has precious little in the way of didactic working-class nobility or cheap gags aimed at the peanut gallery. What it does have is an overwhelming bittersweet melancholy...
It shows that Gwyneth knows the spangly high-powered joys of country music. Too bad that in Country Strong, she's too busy acting out the hysterical and mostly nonsensical sorrows.
It's got videogame-from-hell F/X, plus jousting, plus Cage in tangled long hair he seems to have mistakenly put in the washing machine.
Paul Giamatti, dialing down his trembly-voiced neurotic energy to good effect, gives a holy hell of a performance...
One of those thrillers that pivots around the question of how daring -- or how focus-group cautious -- we suspect the filmmakers will turn out to be.
Insidious is a haunted-house movie that has some of the most shivery and indelible images I've seen in any horror film in decades.
It's Alvin and the Chipmunks with only one chipmunk, and (if possible) even less fun.
It's really a one-joke movie, but the joke is a good one: Frank's ''crusade'' is just a geek's screw-loose revenge, which Wilson, digging into the character's misery, makes oddly sympathetic.
At once open-eyed and myopic, skillful and meandering...
Limitless just wants to give you a good time, and it does, yet the film leaves you wondering: Now that our world has been saturated with antidepressants, is this where big pharma strikes next?
Sketchy and heavy on the treacle.
As Kyle, newcomer Alex Shaffer finds fresh colors in the old delinquent spectrum, and Giamatti, who's at his best, gives nervous scrambling an undertone of tenderness.
Battle: Los Angeles is so inept it's exhausting.
Quote not available.
Has a few token thunderstorm-on-the-moors scenes but lacks a grand, mythological design. The movie is choppy and prosaic.
It makes a few quirky nods toward artistry, but it's really just a glib concoction.
Has the appeal of a middle-aged Before Sunrise.
It does possess a certain backward-glancing innocent appeal.
Cage has forged his own hell, and it's called: the movies he's addicted to making, even when they trash his brand.

Hall Pass, a light comedy of horny marital woe from directors Peter and Bobby Farrelly, makes a novel statement about the sex wars: It says that they're essentially over. And that the guys - in case there was any lingering suspense about it - have lost.
The world's first mumblecore ''thriller" - a good idea for a movie that someone, in the future, should execute a bit less lackadaisically.
Mostly, we're left staring blankly at a quartet of victimized ciphers.
Every movie about cuddly dwarf statues in an English garden should have music this big.
Justin Bieber: Never Say Never may be the concert film as glorified promotional product, but it captures a genuine youthquake.
The sex/class conflicts are way too twee.
Writer-director Gregg Araki makes an unwelcome return to the facile sexual-outlaw posing of his '90s movies.
The Rite commits the supreme sin of making the devil dull.
The Mechanic is ham-fisted pulp, like Robert Rodriguez's Machete taking itself seriously.
It taps into your longing for the days when a sci-fi matrix could explain the world without making it a darker place.
Black Dynamite blends satire, nostalgia, and cinema deconstruction into a one-of-a-kind comedy high.
The power of Nowhere Boy is that, as directed by Sam Taylor-Wood, it captures how John Lennon's deeply sordid family life toyed with his soul by not letting him know who he was.
The Social Network has everything you want in a thriller for the brain: huge doses of ego and duplicity, corporate backstabbing, and some very layered performances.

Countdown to Zero comes close to being nuclear-anxiety porn, yet it's the rare film that could trigger and unite the reflexes   of the left and the right. It makes   getting rid of nukes seem less like a ''cause'' than an imperative.
The Sorcerer's Apprentice is too long, and it's ersatz magic, but at least it casts an ersatz spell.
They're creepy and they're predictable? Mysterious and rather tame?
If The Crow is forgettable entertainment, it can stand as an eerie epitaph for an actor who looked like he was on the way to better things.
Cookie's Fortune is a wittily diagrammed portrait of a small town shaken to its roots by this deceptive calamity. The movie, though, never really becomes more than a diagram.
An enjoyable, minor, lustrously shot revamping of Oscar Wilde's play about the perpetually interlocked manners of love and deception.
Beatty and his team of collaborators have heightened the vibrantly tawdry urban night world of Chester Gould's classic comic strip.

Despite the don't-look-down Olympian settings, Cliffhanger's spirit is brutal and earthbound. The movie is like one of those computer-designed simulator rides that whip you around until you're dizzy and aching but don't actually take you anywhere.
As the Phantom, Billy Zane, buff to the max, has a likable insouciance, but there's not much he can do to flesh out this relic.
The irony of this style, with its high-swank grunge clutter, is that it's too dissociated to have coherence even as pop; we're always aware that we're watching sets being photographed.
Exhaustingly inventive.
The movie, by the end, practically seems intent on destroying itself.
Carrey now has the clout to find a vehicle worthy of his hyperactive gooniness. When he does, we'll see if he's truly a jester for our time or simply the moron of the moment.
Total Recall is too much -- but it's too much of a good thing.
A slick blast of ''decadence,'' the kind of violent swank-trash music video that may make you feel like reaching for the remote control.

Despite some likable performances (Epps is especially winning), the drama in Higher Learning is constricted, hemmed in by Singleton's compulsion to view his characters as walking paradigms of racial and sexual politics.

Ambition is something to respect in an artist, but Charles Burnett's police-corruption drama The Glass Shield is such a maladroit piece of filmmaking that its weighty themes and sclerotic tangle of a plot end up making it a trial to sit through.
In a season dominated by bloated blockbuster wannabes, it's easy to respond to the lean-and-mean B-movie pleasures of Trespass.
Even for teens hooked on the grandiloquence of death-metal masochism, the movie may seem closer to an endless Sunday in church.
The film gives you the pleasurably junky sensation of living inside an apocalyptic videogame.
By now, Jim Carrey is doing sarcastic takes on his own sarcasm, and there's something funny and a little scary in that.
It's amazing it has taken Wallace Shawn, Andre Gregory, and director Louis Malle more than 10 years to collaborate again. It was worth the wait, though.
A dismal, tedious affair.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: The Movie (1990)

movie_review_blurb: It's like a John le Carré double-agent yarn compacted into comic-book pulp as if by the makers of Con Air.
No matter how many wily old Southern coots and rascals Robert Duvall has played, he always finds a way to play another one and make him a fresh, unique presence.
The surreal thing is, Zac Efron can't do despair. He plays it by staring. Blankly. And by not smiling. Blankly.
It's like Deathtrap with two twists instead of 12.
Reeves hasn't just remade the Swedish cult vampire film Let the Right One In into a more fluid and visceral movie. He's made it more dangerous.
As a movie, Freakonomics is like Jujubes for the brain -- it starts to get cloying halfway through the box.
It's a very tony fantasy of class oppression and fascist medical exploitation (themes that may speak louder in England), but it's a lyrically inert movie.
If Lindsay Lohan never makes it back to leading-lady status, then we can all comfort ourselves with the knowledge that we have Emma Stone.
The cast gets some room to improv, and the home-video style -- call it blockbuster mumblecore? -- works cleverly because it emerges right out of the everyone's-an-exhibitionist YouTube age.
Heartbreaker is like a caper comedy meets The Bodyguard -- it's winsome and accomplished fluff.
The movie understands that his Last Honest Man in Showbiz routine is really a performance -- even if it's one the actor himself is only dimly aware of.
Lacks the Coen brothers' precision, their diabolical game-board cleverness. It's a remake in shaggy outline only.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: See Machete for Trejo, who barely cracks a smile, or even an emotion, but makes grade-Z stoic invincibility cool again.
Going the Distance may be a minor movie, but it's also the rare romantic comedy in which you can actually believe what you're seeing.
The American ends the summer not with a bang but an existential whimper.
Secretariat, a benignly inspirational Disney sports drama about the legendary racehorse who won the Triple Crown in 1973, offers a fascinating test case for how much spoilers sometimes don't matter.
Quote not available.
The Tillman Story unravels the deceptions -- and the deep dishonor -- that inflated life-size valor into fake superheroism.
It's about the dark side of piety -- the cultish wrath that can emerge out of the high and the mighty. At the center of it all, once again, is a teenage girl's gnashing wrath.
A pop history lesson that holds you, but it's no deeper than an E! True Hollywood Story.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to imagine how scenes of mass dismemberment set during a wet T-shirt contest could be staged any better.
The Switch squeezes fresh laughs out of what is, in essence, a rather startlingly post-Freudian, nature-trumps-nurture view of child development.
Soon sinks into a bog of overly murky narrative.
It plants resonant doubts.
It's a true original.
As for Stallone, he grimaces purposefully in his El Greco beard, and he keeps the body count coming so that it sates you like a junk-food craving fulfilled.
It's a comedy of manhood for the age of emasculation.
The dance sequences are glittery, percussive explosions of citified youth energy.
The events may be accurate, but Mesrine is so episodic that it's slightly maddening to watch.
Chris Rock's deeply funny and very serious documentary about the African-American obsession with straightened tresses.
Thanks to Vaughn, Favreau, and the stray sharp lines that pop out of everyone else, the film at least offers the lively sound of egos that still know how to swing.
A lyrical and stirring meditation on the mystery of autism.
The fun of Role Models is that it's a high-concept movie executed with speed and finesse and the kind of brusquely tossed-off obscene banter that can get you laughing before you know what hit you.
A glibly entertaining corporate thriller.

High School Musical 3: Senior Year gives you an honest jolt of feel-good fizz. It may be as friendly and square as one of those 1950s teen romps in which the actors wore letter sweaters, but that doesn't mean the movie is an uptight anachronism.

The oldfangled deliberateness of Eastwood's style has backfired this time, only adding to the sense that though you may not have heard this particular story before, you already know everything that's coming.

I gave up making heads or tails of Synecdoche, New York, but I did get one message: The compulsion to stand outside of one's life and observe it to this degree isn't the mechanism of art -- it's the structure of psychosis.
If random arty blood thrills are your cup of fear, perhaps you'll enjoy Let the Right One In, a Swedish head-scratcher that has a few creepy images but very little holding them together.
Stranded, which combines testimony by those survivors with staged reenactments of their ordeal, is the opposite of sensational.
movie_title: Stranded: I Have Come from a Plane That Crashed on the Mountains (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is a series of glum interrogation scenes that lead nowhere special, with a not-quite-sci-fi urban murkiness that makes it look like someone was trying to shoot Blade Runner in Cleveland.
Isn't it time that Hollywood took a sabbatical -- maybe a permanent one -- from movies in which black characters exist primarily to save the souls of white ones?
It has dryly obscene, laugh-out-loud lines, and its portrait of Hollywood as a giant anxiety attack is fused by De Niro, who musters a desperate, nagging warmth beneath his grumbly facade.

Sex Drive twits its own lost innocence with a knowing backward glance (the winsome leads deserve a more humane movie), and Seth Green is uproarious as an Amish farmer who speaks in sentences so passive-aggressive, they're like tiny slaps.
The movie is short on wisdom, but it might have gotten by if it had had better filth.
I don't know whether the Bond series has a future, but if Xenia Onatopp ever returns to try for world domination, he may finally get a battle worth fighting.
Ritchie concocts a crime-jungle demimonde that's organically linked to the real world, and it's a damn fun one to visit.

Working from a screenplay by William Monahan, Scott takes rusty '80s clichés from the days when we were playing nuclear chicken with Russia and retrofits them to the post-9/11 world. He exposes how weary those old spy tropes really are.
Demme's finest work since The Silence of the Lambs, and a movie that tingles with life.
As the movie comes into focus, you feel the lives of the characters echoing backward through time.

It's a film that's destined to make a lot of people mad, but Maher, for all his showy atheistic 'doubt,' isn't just trying to crucify religion -- he truly wants to know what makes it tick. He leaves no stone tablet unturned.
You could say Beverly Hills Chihuahua is Lady and the Tramp meets Viva Zapata!, but seriously, I've seen zestier attitude in a Purina commercial.
Moore's studentmobilization drive now looks prescient, but he should have kept this piece of wallpaper agitprop on the shelf.
It sounds like a bad TV movie, yet Stuart Townsend, the veteran actor-turned-director re-creates it all with stunning passion and skill in Battle in Seattle.
It's an indelibly warped cartoon of lust and despair.
The Lucky Ones isn't dull, and the actors do quite nicely, especially McAdams, who's feisty, gorgeous, and as mercurial as a mood ring.
It's just another grumpy-old-men grousefest with a gooey center, like The Sunshine Boys or The Bucket List. Even its musical nostalgia comes off as more concocted than felt.

Gini Reticker's simply made, affecting documentary Pray the Devil Back to Hell reveals how these heroic ordinary women prodded the factions to peace and literally brought down Taylor, a leader of sociopathic cruelty.
movie_title: Pray the Devil Back to Hell (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Slumdog Millionaire is nothing if not an enjoyably far-fetched piece of rags-to-riches wish fulfillment. It's like the Bollywood version of a Capra fable sprayed with colorful drops of dark-side-of-the-Third-World squalor.

Eden lacks the technique to give its stifled domestic-erotic feelings their full power. Yet Kelly and Walsh, who has a shy sensuality that pokes out of her toothy homely beauty, are emotionally eloquent.
Twice as long as it needs to be, but it is also only half the movie it should have been.
He's made a film that embraces the romance of revolution only to shake it off, leaving very little in its place.
Hoffman and Thompson are each good enough to bring out a glow in the other.
Bride Wars pretends to be a satire of wedding mania, but since there's virtually nothing else to the movie, the satire comes depressingly close to endorsement.
The best thing about Revolutionary Road... is that it doesn't end with that rote vision of bourgeois anomie. It only begins there.
A disarmingly enjoyable, wholehearted comic vision of the happy messiness of family life.
Full of burnt-end romance and 'style,' but robotic at its core.
It's a dispirited, galumphing mess in which Sandler, as a hotel handyman who spins out tall tales for his niece and nephew, pictures himself in assorted historical-kitsch guises.
It has more chuckles than guffaws, maybe because Carrey has always been a comic actor who says yes yes yes. Literalizing that impulse only robs it of surprise.
The director, Paul Schrader, tries for cleansing audacity, but ends up too close to farce.
The original Day the Earth Stood Still had a paranoid poetry that lifted the audience up even as it warned the world to come together. This one is so dour it just comes off as a scolding.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Miracle at St. Anna wants to do too many things at once to do any of them with much verve. It aspires to be a war epic, but it's dominated less by combat than by flat, meandering talk.
Nothing But the Truth has been made with brains, pace, and skill, and with a topical fury that puts it ahead of the curve on its real subject: the withering of freedom in a democracy gone apathetic.
The director, Randall Miller, appears to be trying to cross a bad Elmore Leonard thriller with a bad indie-festival family-angst comedy.
Wendy and Lucy is like Lassie Come Home directed by Antonioni.
Cadillac Records lacks a center, yet it's an enjoyable ramble, with a feel for what made the early days of rock as wild as any that followed.
[An] incisive and stirring dramatization of Harvey Milk's heroic life and violent death.
It's four home-for-the-holidays comedies in one, and the variety-pack structure works for the movie: Each nightmare household has a wacked flavor all its own, and none wears out its welcome.
The Guitar is a lark, at best, but when Burrows' healing indulgence extends to taking on lovers of both sexes, its goofiness acquires a certain hedonistic charm.
The past-and-present layering is a lot more resonant -- and less sketchy -- than the film's theme of 'betrayal,' both familial and governmental.
Hardwicke stirs this teen pulp to a pleasing simmer.
Imagine two movies plucked from opposite sides of the video store.
Quote not available.

The backstories keep piling up, with nods to The Shining, The Ring, and a dozen other gothic supernatural chillers, yet the result doesn't remotely scare you -- rather, it keeps explaining why you should be scared. That's why we're not.
The Wrestler is like Rocky made by the Scorsese of Mean Streets. It's the rare movie fairy tale that's also a bravura work of art.

Notorious is a luridly unapologetic trip through the violence, hunger, verbal bravado, and money fever of the hip-hop world, which it views as both liberating and destructive (often for the same reasons).
Even the title is a letdown, somehow.
If you want to hear juicy inside tales of the scams devised by Lee Atwater, the right-wing visionary of media-age dirty tricks, you'll find loads of them in Boogie Man.
movie_title: Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: I won't really defend Mamma Mia!, but I will recommend how to watch it: Just stop rolling your eyes and listen.
Anyone who thinks that Josh Hartnett isn't a true movie star should see his riveting, high-wire performance in August, a shrewdly dramatized look back at the bursting of the dot-com bubble.

In this, the last performance he completed before his death, Ledger had a maniacal gusto inspired enough to suggest that he might have lived to be as audacious an actor as Marlon Brando, and maybe as great.
Wandering around the earth's stalactite-dripped core exerts a primal appeal even in a dumb kiddie joyride like this one.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: To make a comic-book fantasy this derivative yet this dazzling requires more than technique. It takes a director in touch with his inner hellboy.
Adapted from the 2003 Monica Ali novel, Brick Lane is one of those feminist cries in the dark in which the heroine, a saintly sufferer, is more admirable than interesting.
Gonzo, the documentary by Alex Gibney, taps the full fascination of its subject: Dr. Hunter S. Thompson.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Jonathan Levine's The Wackness is a studiously offbeat coming-of-age crowd-pleaser set in New York City during the long-ago, far-away days of...the summer of 1994.
An exultant comedy of American repression and revolt.
It whisks you to another world, then makes it every inch our own.

If you're in the mood for a delightful tweak of today's self-actualizing New Age gurus, look elsewhere. If, on the other hand, you want to see gags about boogers, elephant poop, and mano-a-mano duels with mops drenched in urine, then this is for you.

As a satire of new-style collegiate types, this MTV production actually evinces a few germs of rancid wit. If only the laborious high-concept plot had been deep-sixed -- and, along with it, the cynically blah heroes.
The first road movie that could fit into the mumblecore genre of dithering youth angst: The Go-Getter travels, but it doesn't go anywhere.
[Herzog] wants us to see how these quirky researchers, in their lust to explore, are acting out a drive as primitive as nature: the need to break away from the world in order to find it.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The audience, in all likelihood, will be so grateful not to see another joyless, inert, pea green dud that it may not mind that The Incredible Hulk is just a luridly reductive and violent B movie -- one that clears a bar that hadn't been set very high.
Graham is charming, but Miss Conception is a cloddish biological-clock bedroom farce.
In The Mother of Tears, the last installment of the 'witch trilogy' that began, three decades ago, with Suspiria, an excavated urn unleashes a torrent of homicidal madness in Rome.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: When Did You Last See Your Father? taps into the conflicting feelings so many of us can have about parents who haunt us because they're difficult, which is part of what makes them irreplaceable.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Just about all animated movies teach you to Believe in Yourself, but the image of a face-stuffing panda-turned-yowling Bruce Lee dervish is as unlikely, and touching, an advertisement for that message as we've seen in quite some time.
Savage Grace has been shot with decadent cool creaminess, yet it's a rather slipshod movie.
An overbearing lampoon of American war profiteering -- a comedy so leaden it could make a liberal hate liberal Hollywood.
Stuart Gordon, the mostly under-the-radar director of Re-Animator, pops back into view with this amusing trifle -- a piece of scuzzy tabloid noir.
It sounds stupid enough, and ultimately is, but the director, Bryan Bertino, stages The Strangers' early scenes with spooky panache.
This luminously shot concert movie reveals that Berlin is far from the lost masterpiece the movie wants it to be.
A ghostly and startling tale of Native Americans in Los Angeles -- a fusion of documentary and fiction -- in the late '50s. Never previously released, it's a revelation.
Step Brothers is hit-and-miss, but it made me wish that the usual American comedy of 'how stupid can we get?' had this much rage.
Brideshead Revisited is opulent and watchable, yet except for Thompson's acting, it's missing something -- a grander, more ambivalent vision of the England it depicts dying out.
Appaloosa is a pleasingly spacious piece of work, but for all of its little tangles it never musters the kick of a psychological duel.
As it becomes clear that Ball, in essence, has just restaged American Beauty with a socially conscious paint job, the sensationalism of Towelhead looks more and more like a dramatic tic.
The Women is such an arduous patchwork of 'issues' it ends up a Frankenstein's monster of a chick flick.
[Cage takes] the big bucks to star in slovenly, inert pulp of the sort no actor of his magnitude should be stooping to.
Even those of us who find anti-homosexual 'deprogramming' to be hideously intolerant and naive may find ourselves oddly relieved that Mark is there.
Friendly yet toothless, College musters little energy even as anarchic-party-movie nostalgia.
Since many of the targets (Cloverfield, Hancock, Kung Fu Panda) already have a cheeky self-consciousness, the comedy rarely seems more than a hasty patchwork of cheap-shot allusions.
The director, Alexandre Aja, knows how to reflect the fear in people's heads, but he gets too ensnared in a backstory that's just gothic business as usual.
A sharp, absorbing portrait of our national debt crisis.
Azazel Jacobs, the writer-director of Momma's Man, has done more than make another precious indie family quirkfest; he's created a true vision.
A high school musical that would make John Waters proud.
It's not much fun to see these two reduced to Mad TV parodies of themselves. In the right movie, they'd stop coasting on their legends long enough to remind us how they became them.
The only brazen thing about the film is how shamelessly it rips off School of Rock.
Gooey, ponderous, and maudlin. It's less a tale of religious rebirth than a faith-based Hallmark card.
George Lucas is turning into the enemy of fun.
Turns into an Internet Age version of Before Sunrise.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: West does an earnest job, but that's the problem: He never conjures Crash's psychotic danger. Neither does this eager, flawed, scrappy biopic.
It's a claustrophobic dud, full of ludicrously purple tough-guy dialogue and lip-smacking vamps in bikinis (how hot!), with so much monotonous hip violence there's scarcely room for anything else.
The politics of making wine is a great subject for a movie, but this clunker doesn't do it justice; Bottle Shock is broad and coy where it needs to be smart.
Director Isabel Coixet sees David's tragedy, but also his life force, and she draws brilliant work out of Cruz.

Pineapple Express is a fitfully amusing tale of drugs and crooks and general dilapidation, but the more it goes on, and the loopier it gets, the less it connects with experience. It becomes Apatow's hash-bar version of a cynical action joyride.
The climactic game, in which Roy, in a way that defies prediction, attempts to sink the shot of his life, is the most rousing sequence of the year, a celebration of what it really means to win.

In Frozen River, [Melissa] Leo's acting has a brittle severity and power. Every moment of her performance feels torn from experience, and so does the movie, which finds a suspense in broken lives that are hanging in the balance.
Fraser, who at 39 looks perhaps five years older than this kid, needed a wholesome offspring-sidekick like a third arm. Then again, it's not clear that the world needed a third Mummy movie.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The 3-D animation work in Fly Me to The Moon is brisk and sweet.

Mary is a spiritual descendant of Holly Golightly, and there's an echo, as well, of Edie Sedgwick, the late Andy Warhol superstar who moved the American-princess-on-a-bender mythology into the drug-rock era.
Good has a stagy fustiness, but it's worth seeing for Mortensen, who makes this study of   a 'good German' look creepily contemporary. He shows us the horror   of ignorance.
Chandni Chowk to China is the first Bollywood movie to be released in the U.S. in the wake of the Bollywood-inflected Slumdog Millionaire. Let's hope it's not the last.
[Nanni] Moretti makes this 'study' in despair a naggingly neutral, at times borderline coy experience.
Arlen's salvation plays out with tender cloying predictability, though Lauren Graham, as the chiropractor who falls for him, has more spark than the movie deserves.
It wants to be Good Will Hunting set in the land of Entourage, but its bummed-out touchy-feeliness is every bit  as concocted as its overly jaded showbiz corruption.

The Beaches of Agnès taps a haunting nostalgia, because it invites the art-house  audience to get wistful for what it once was - that is, for a time when an artist like Varda only had to dream it, and we would come.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Ugly Truth isn't fizzy and fun -- it's vacuously snappy.
It's a Gen-Y Annie Hall made by a new-style Wes Anderson who uses his cleverness for humanity instead of postmodern superiority.
Blood: The Last Vampire might be described as Kill Bill crossed with Buffy, only that would make it sound like more than the slapdash, thrill-less dud that it is.
What's infectious in Soul Power is the almost shocking optimism of its America-meets- Africa '70s world-beat vibe.
The movie is a toxic dart aimed at the spangly new heart of American hypocrisy: our fake-tolerant, fake-charitable, fake-liberated-yet-still madly-closeted fame culture.
A grubby, disturbing serial-killer mystery, a kind of blood-simple Rashomon.
Nice, sweet, safe.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: These two lovebirds are playfully mismatched, and that's just why they fall for each other.
Revenge of the Fallen may be a massive overdose of popcorn greased with motor oil. But it knows how to feed your inner 10-year-old's appetite for destruction.
This passionate ecological documentary, The End of the Line, spells out the problem in clear, urgent, prosaic terms.
Tetro fuses the awkward and the ripely operatic.
Platt, more than anyone, is the soul of the movie, because he makes even the most  primitive perversity sound...well, civilized.
An essential, disturbing portrait of how the food we eat in America has become a deceptively prefab, even hazardous industrial product.

Moon is the first feature to be directed by Duncan Jones, who is David Bowie's son, and he brings it a grimy industrial look, as well as witty touches like giving Gerty a smiley-face screen that changes expression in tandem with Spacey's voice.
Imagine That is a benignly didactic kiddie movie that at once benefits from and gets buried under Eddie Murphy's skittery, overeager inflections.

What makes the movie a trial to sit through isn't just the heroine's pain-freak tastes. It's that a kinkfest with this blah an emotional spectrum is selling its own chic form of puritanism -- sex with all the life force repressed.
My Life in Ruins is a middle-aged Hallmark chick flick that makes you wish you were on a Greek vacation (and not, in fact, watching the movie).
Land of the Lost has stray amusing  tidbits, but overall it leaves you feeling splattered.

A gilded entry in the cinema du quirk. It's a movie that invites you, all too often, to feel superior to the people on screen. Yet it's been designed, shot, and edited with unusual finesse, and the two main characters are fresh screen types.
To really get under your skin, a bad-seed horror movie needs a demon child whose dastardliness sneaks up on you. There's nothing too subtle, however, about Esther.
Adam is sweet, meticulous, and, at times, sort of clever, but it's also a not-quite-surprising-enough heartwarming trifle.
The Cove doesn't always give you the facts you want. Yet its images of blood in the water are worth a thousand preachy words.
You can feel the shadow of Steven Spielberg's Munich hovering over Flame & Citron, a Danish drama of resistance fighters in Copenhagen during WWII.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The French director Cédric Klapisch is a glib wizard at weaving folks together, but there are too many secondhand characters roving through Paris, his latest ensemble piece.
With its this-is-really-happening vibe, Paranormal Activity scrapes away 30 years of encrusted nightmare clichés. The fear is real, all right, because the fear is really in you.
More Than a Game is a documentary, but it's every inch a triumph-of-the-underdogs fairy tale.
A Serious Man isn't perfect -- I'm still grappling with the powerfully offbeat ending -- but it's cathartic to see the Coens finally show you a bit of who they are, or at least where they came from.
At its best, Capitalism: A Love Story is a searing outcry against the excesses of a cutthroat time. At its worst, it's dorm-room Marxism.
he film is consistently fun, and Tucker's comeuppance   will leave you gasping (if not gagging) with laughter.
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Krasinski preserves Wallace's whooshing roller coasters of words, powered by the fuel of confession.
Though [Koreeda] has made a film of droll and dry observational precision, its emotional minimalism is almost fetishistic -- and, by the end, a tad frustrating.
Douglas makes smarm a chewy pleasure, but this is a noir in search of a hero we can root for because we actually buy what he's doing.
As the brutish Kable, Gerard Butler must find out who's pulling his strings, but it's the audience whose chain gets yanked by this headache-inducing techno-violent mishmash.
Didn't Judge realize that Extract, with its plastic setups and one-dimensional harpies, plays like Kevin Smith remaking a bad George Segal comedy from 1978?
The Hangover has scattered laughs (many in the cathartically funny end-credit montage), but overall it's more amusing than hilarious.
An unblinking look at the hidden (or perhaps not so   hidden) pathology of American sports mania, in which the power and victory of your team becomes the sole conduit for your self-worth.
Once again, a group of pretty young things who have escaped the opening disaster proceed to die, one by one, as fate catches up with them.
World's Greatest Dad, Bobcat Goldthwait's latest garishly potty-mouthed and over-the-top black comedy, blows up every rule of taste, good cinema, and common sense, and somehow gets away with it.
Lee captures the fractious, joyful, monstrously evolving mass it all was.

I came away from The September Issue liking Anna Wintour more than I thought I would, but mostly with an appreciation for her mission: not just to sell magazines, to market clothing and style, but to give femininity its sheen.
A rapturous and enlightening look at the history of the environmental movement in America.
It Might Get Loud is a marvelous rock doc that manages to be wistful, tasty, and jam-kicking at the same time.
Is there anything soggier than a cad redeemed?
The Time Traveler's Wife is built as a game that the audience learns to play, and after a while, yes, we do get the hang of it.
There are fine, fresh observational moments, but the film is much ado about not so much.
A sub-Saw knockoff that manages to be brutal yet monotonous, not to mention monstrously unpleasant.
Though hardly a perfect soufflé, Julie & Julia is the movie American foodie culture has been waiting for. It hooks you up, happily, to your inner top chef.
An entertaining but also oddly naive documentary about American advertising.
Defiance bogs down in a not very well-developed script. It's a repetitive stop-and-start action film, and Tuvia and Zus don't have enough layers.  But they do kick ass charismatically.
Like Sunshine Cleaning, this is a gentle comic tale of grisly  employment opportunity in desperate times. Only Departures is tender and, at times, rather squishy.
Going back to his roots, Raimi has made the most crazy, fun, and terrifying horror movie in years.
Whenever Sin Nombre turns violent, it seizes you with its convulsive skill, but the film's images   vastly outstrip its imagination.
The Great Buck Howard is in love with kitsch, the backwaters of showbiz, and true magic. It's  a wee charmer that left me enchanted.

Paul Rudd gives a startlingly funny and original performance as a nice guy with serious dweebish tendencies, and the delight of what Rudd does here comes down to how exquisitely embarrassing he is to watch.
Anyone who goes to see Miss March hoping for a voyeuristic, '80-flavored T&A smutfest will be sorely disappointed.
Everlasting Moments is all staged as a harsh poem of survival, with no great psychological interest, yet the ending carries a surprise feminist tug that's worth the wait.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This remake is merely vile (and dull), with a badly miscast Tony Goldwyn as the raging dad who makes revenge for his daughter's violation look more gratuitously brutal than the crime.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What looks like a drama of adultery turns out to be an exploration of how the spaces between people can separate them or join them, often at the same moment.
...he's far more candid recalling his grand delusions in a school play than he is when he gets to Broadway and Hollywood.
It's bloated, heavy-handed, and lugubrious.

Two of the cast members shine: Lou Taylor Pucci as a drug dealer who finds a new lover and baptizes himself in substance abuse, and Rosario Dawson as a mother trying to care for her asthmatic son with no health insurance.
Phoebe appears to have obsessive-compulsive disorder (or something), but Phoebe in Wonderland is so intent on celebrating her as 'special' that it quirks up the trauma of her issues.
Watchmen isn't boring, but as a fragmented sci-fi doomsday noir, it remains as detached from the viewer as it is from the zeitgeist.
Scott Walker: 30 Century Man is the latest in a mini-wave of pop-music docs, like The Devil and Daniel Johnston, that try to inflate cult figures into lost geniuses.
Director Wayne Kramer crisscrosses these stories into a diverting anthropological melodrama, with enough  coincidence to keep the action unified.
Tyler Perry's latest soul operetta lives up to the mischief promised by its title. But that isn't nearly enough of the time.

The teensploitation premise is like something a porn filmmaker from the '70s might have come up with. But Fired Up! has one added quirk: The script, credited to Freedom Jones, is a riot of tongue-twisting ironic sleaze.

You have to watch it with different brain muscles than you're used to using, because the film has no frills or hooks, no visible 'arcs,' nothing to grab on to but the fragile humanity of the people on screen.
From its talking storewindow mannequins to its sneaky debauched heroine, the movie is romantic-comedy fizz, but it's fizz that bubbles like champagne.
He's Just Not That Into You turns romantic sanity into something so sanitized that it starts to make delusion look good.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Pink Panther 2 provides genial chuckles, but it's never excitingly rude.
We don't feel much of anything.
Smith isn't just fooling around anymore.
It's like Paul Schrader's 1979 Hardcore with no brain and more muscle.
If you want to know how inept the movie is...well, it's so inept that you may wish you were watching an M. Night Shyamalan version of the very same premise.
Ritter, who's like the young Ethan Hawke on a bender of violence, is an actor to watch.
A shrewdly made documentary about the rise and fall of Plato's Retreat, the infamous Manhattan sex club of the '70s and '80s.
Adventureland doesn't quite soar -- it lopes along affectionately. But for nostalgia junkies, it's one from the heart.

In this enjoyably dirty-minded sendup of when-ballet-met-hip-hop youth musicals, the Wayans brothers hand the directorial reigns over to their nephew, Damien Dante Wayans, who piles on the stupid/smart gags with just the right what-the-hell abandon.
The Girlfriend Experience is one of Steven Soderbergh's bite-size, semi-improvised, shot-on-DV doodles, and it's the best one he's made
This is what you call a wholesome kiddie movie on drugs.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The whole movie is a bit of a machine.
An indie dud.

As long as Revanche focuses on the relationship between Tamara (Irina Potapenko), an indentured Ukrainian prostitute, and Alex (Johannes Krisch), the ex-con gofer and would-be tough guy who wants to help her escape, it's riveting.
The novelty here, and it's a good one, is that Johnson decorates and deepens the gamesmanship with tender shoots of family feeling.
Atom Egoyan's latest glum puzzle is a meditation on post-9/11 hysteria, but it's too much 'What's the meaning of terrorism?' cud chewing too late.
Pattinson and Beltran are stuck with a rudderless script, and they make a soft, dull pair.

You'd expect a documentary about closeted gay politicians who hide their sexuality behind virulently antigay voting records to be a diatribe. But Kirby Dick's furious, deft, revealing film is  humane enough to separate the sinner from the sin.
With a crew like this, you can welcome the future.

Jessica Biel in a teacup-rattling '20s period piece? With her lewd pinup grin and husky flat voice, she sticks out like a sore starlet in Easy Virtue -- but that's the whole point in this loosely 'freshened up' version of a Noël Coward play.
The Limits of Control, even with its flow of star cameos (Tilda Swinton, Gael García Bernal, a frenetic Bill Murray), is a listless long pause that rarely refreshes.
It's by far the most slack, ho-hum movie ever made from Ellis' material.
It's doubtful that Obsessed will stick in the popular imagination for more than two weeks, because the movie is borderline ludicrous, and it jams its characters into rigid slots.
A movie as layered and enthralling as its subject.
It's all a bit shapeless, yet made with sincerity and taste, and the two actors seize your sympathy.
[An] excitingly twisty and topical new politics-and-media conspiracy thriller.
Cyrus, as always, is a professional charmer (it's hard to resist when she leads a hip-hop hoedown), and the crusty folkiness of Billy Ray Cyrus as her real-life dad is as welcome as ever.
A stillborn rendering of Michael Chabon's first novel.
It's a hilarious, and unexpectedly moving, documentary about the greatest metal band you've probably never heard of.

The 'spicy' numbers have no dazzle, the actors mug like contestants in a Maurice Chevalier impersonation contest, and the plot is a drily indigestible wad of show-must-go-on preciousness and socialist sentimentality.
A playful, elusive movie that isn't so much heartwarming as soul-cleansing.
This is a sports drama of total originality, as well as the most authentic inside view of the immigrant experience the movies have given us in quite a while.
The movie is cheesy, tacky, and gimmicky. But as directed by Mark Waters, it's also prankish and inventive enough to be kind of fun.

When you behold the teen boogie skaters of Roll Bounce, which is set in Chicago in 1978, those funky/silly movements give you a happy jolt of pleasure. It's hard not to notice that the kitschiness of the dancing is what makes it so...optimistic.
Barely gets off the ground.
As an achievement in macabre visual wizardry, Tim Burton's Corpse Bride has to be reckoned some sort of marvel.
Smith, coming off the madly audacious Dogma, knows that he's slumming this time and revels in it.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The wanly watchable Summer Catch ... could mark the official commencement of Prinze's Nelson-ization.

The gimmicks, in the end, are too arbitrary to tie together in a memorably haunting fashion, though they do culminate in a Big Twist, a nifty one that almost -- but not quite -- makes you want to see the movie again.
The Dutch director Pierre Paul Renders ingeniously conjures the image of a control freak society that is sinister in its very playfulness.
A marvel of vérité nightmare atmosphere.
A textbook case of a movie that would have been better had it been worse.
Apocalypse Now Redux is the meandering, indulgent art project that he was still enough of a craftsman, in 1979, to avoid.
See it for Swinton's embodiment of unadulterated maternal will.
Features backlot spectacle, a cast of hundreds battle, a weak whisper of gladiatorial vengeance -- everything, in fact, but imagination.
A loving and meticulous re-creation of the last moment before American youth culture went permanently ironic.
The whole movie is diagrammed. It's a just-add-water trifle.
Evokes the intimacies of teenage girls with unusual delicacy, and Perabo's performance is a geyser of emotion.
A buoyant, funny, and disarmingly humane comedy of beautiful losers in revolt.
Am I the only one who finds [Kitano's] films impossible to make heads or tails of?
Spielberg's wizardry is gone, and his balletic light touch as well, and that gives too much of this 90-minute movie over to the duller-than-dull characters.
An act of nose-thumbing that never quite figures out how, or even where, to position its thumb.
A caterwauling punk anthem on film, a vengeful fantasia served up with digital rawness.
A sturdily diverting old fashioned heist thriller.
A movie that aspires to be Muriel's Wedding and can't muster the proper wacky fraudulence to achieve that goal is a sad spectacle indeed.

Made is little more than a rambling chain of combative buddy mishaps, but the interplay between Vaughn and Favreau, who does great double takes of thrusting chin frustration, spins you through the weak patches.
The movie's brew of exploitation and guilt is messagey in the worst way.
What holds the movie together ... is Gibson's broodingly responsive performance.
Dunst, in her finest performance yet, has now transcended her fellow teen stars.
Yet another hyperbolic slasher cartoon.
As brilliant as Rock can be, this material is a reflection of his shallow, moralistic side.
To an astonishing degree, O gets the tragic Shakespeare mood, that somber stentorian passion born of hidden slivers of ambition and betrayal.
It's not every comedy that can make you laugh with ridicule and cringe in empathetic horror at the same time.
Despite an evocatively dark-toned DV atmosphere, is too responsible to erupt into the kind of operatic maternal horror it keeps threatening the audience with.
There are many things wrong with Novocaine, but the film's most gnawing pain is its clodhopper farfetchedness.
Hawke releases his inner actor, and it's a kick to see.
Inflated with a doom that feels programmatic rather than earned.
movie_title: The Town Is Quiet (La Ville est tranquille) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: It takes a very intense actor to seize an audience by appearing to do almost nothing.
We watch good Jet battle evil Jet ... and the difference between the characters boils down to... blank and slightly less blank.
On the Line would like to be Serendipity for the Oxy-and-Skechers set, but it feels more like the worst movie Michael J. Fox never made.
It seems to unfold in some implausible twilight zone of Crayola ethics.
Here, as in that overheated political circus The Contender, Lurie demonstrates his weakness for heavy-handed 'topical' dialectics.
This is the rare contemporary whodunit that truly works.
Introduces this sissy boy of a hero and proceeds to bland out everything that's ridiculous about him.
Mulholland Drive may on some level be a sacramental dream as rerun, but Lynch is such a hypnotic craftsman that he holds you in his thrall.
There may be whispers of reality to this abandon- all-hope vision of Argentina, but it's a truth presented didactically, without eloquence, vitality, or a mordant glimmer of spirit.
Is whimsicality the last refuge of the mediocre?
Designed as a kind of folkie infomercial to elevate David Grisman to the status of legend.
The first food movie to capture the joyful civilized mania of people who live not just to eat but to talk about eating.
The heart of the movie is dull.
An enthralling look at the drama that can transpire in the autumn of one small town on any given Friday.
Hearts in Atlantis is too poky and contrived to be a good movie, but its lushly serene atmospherics, given current events, make it a pure slice of sentimental comfort food.
Carey is weirdly blank and recessive.
Kornbluth, with his softly discombobulated rage, makes you want to see more of him.
You know you're in the hands of a born filmmaker when he floods a scene with danger and excitement and, at the same time, tempers it with something more delicate.
Is a case of synthetic sensationalism, a glorified star-image makeover that grows glossier and more monotonous as it goes along.
This is the rare movie that gets you to fall in love with characters you don't even like.
Works hard to be exciting, but the movie scarcely lives up to its title.
There's only one performer in the movie who looks completely at ease with what he's doing: the horse.
Collectively, the numbers add up to a triumph of ecstatic mood swinging.
In its low grade way, this blithely brutal cops and drugs thriller is an efficient hot wire entertainment.
Get Over It is mostly an amateur hour fiasco.
A moody craftsman of dazzling vision and skill.
A jumping off point for showy, contrived, borderline exploitation sequences that fail to tie together because they're not really there to do anything but sell themselves as money shot thrills.

Moving and eerily beautiful.
The movie has the look and feel of one of those Saturday Night Live miniparodies that's exquisitely clever and close to the bone.

Born Into Brothels is designed to be 'inspirational,' yet it shortchanges the complex reality of the lives it makes such a show of saving.
We can glory, for an hour or two, in the splendors of a life based on renunciation -- and then return, without having to renounce anything ourselves, to a life of unrigorous indulgence.
Will the audience follow Ice Cube on this road trip to benign banality? Here's hoping he books a nonstop return ticket.

Jean-François Ríchet, the director of the new Assault, is working from a script, by James DeMonaco, that creates a handful of zingy one-note lowlifes but that hasn't updated the isolated-precinct premise in a timely or thoughtful way.
Lior Ashkenazi, who stars in it as an emotionally buttoned-down Mossad agent, has the debonair subtlety and charisma of an Israeli Clive Owen.
Now here's a daring version of l'amour fou.
The best reason to see Melinda and Melinda is Radha Mitchell, who has her grabbiest role (or two of them) since she broke through with High Art.

[A] handsome but curiously remote Crusades epic.

It takes talent to entice an audience without any dialogue. In the case of South Korea's Kim Ki-Duk, he's not just good at silence; his oddball artistry depends on it.
This is that rare B movie that's rooted in gut-level stirrings of power and retaliation.
A Lot Like Love is a lot like a romantic comedy, except that all that's keeping these two kids apart is the trivially insufferable movie they're in.

movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: So unoriginal that the movie could almost be a parody of J-horror tropes, yet Miike, for a while at least, stages it with a dread-soaked visual flair that allows you to enjoy being manipulated.
That rare event: a memorable provocation.
Moodysson comes on like de Sade crossed with Godard, yet by locking us outside of his characters, he fails to make them even contemptuously compelling.
movie_title: Hål i mitt hjärta, Ett (A Hole In My Heart) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The most crackerjack entertainment I've seen so far this year.
A skillful and winning piece of honest booster portraiture directed by James D. Stern and Adam Del Deo.
It's been a while since a movie made the game of love this winning.

It took gifted hucksters to make this movie.

Putting an interracial love story on screen may have been bold in 1967, but by now it should be more casual than it is. The skittish, focus-grouped blandness of Guess Who comes through in the flavorlessness of the romance.

A glimpse into a society that has grown more open, more free, and also more casually selfish in its interpersonal aggression.
An amazing and profoundly disturbing experience.

Fascinating bare-bones documentary.

movie_review_blurb: Lee, as he did in Malcolm X and Clockers, makes his hero's dread palpable, and though 25th Hour lacks the glittering brilliance of those films, I was held by the toughness and pity of Lee's gaze.

A likable throwaway.

movie_review_blurb: The Israel Ben-Gurion talks about is more than a fading memory; it now seems a distant planet. Yet there are moments when he seems to look forward, with prophetic insight, at much of what has happened since.
What begins as a celebration of reckless freedom, then turns into a revelation of a broken soul, becomes something deeper ...
"The Boss Baby" still feels standard issue and a wee bit tiresome.
Watching "Love & Taxes," you feel as if you're witnessing a life presented without much filter. It's Kornbluth's willingness to revel in what a screw-up he is that carries you along.
