If you're a fan of the first two movies, it's hard to imagine that you won't like this one.

The film is beautifully acted by Shahab Hosseini, who makes Emad a knight with a control freak inside, and Taraneh Alidootsi, who suggests a woeful Iranian version of Marion Cotillard. But the great performance here is that of Babak Karimi.
"The Circle" is a swankly sinister little mind teaser of a thriller. It's a nightmare vision of what digital culture is turning all of us into, with all of our help.
"Whitney: 'Can I Be Me'" has no conspiracies to uncover. It just has a story to tell, and it does that incredibly compellingly.

"The Mummy" is a literal-minded, bumptious monster mash of a movie. It keeps throwing things at you, and the more you learn about the ersatz intricacy of its "universe," the less compelling it becomes.

Even with a subject as great as Cary Grant, and a take on him that appears to have all its metaphysical Old Hollywood signifiers in place, "Becoming Cary Grant" is a murky and rather disappointing biographical portrait.
Two elements - America and Elvis - come together in ticklish, surprising ways that expand and delight your perceptions.

"Captain Underpants" isn't out to be more than a trifle; that's part of its appeal. It's not so much potty-mouthed as it is a potty-minded kiddie burlesque, one that finds the supreme innocence in naughtiness.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A small, watchable, rather prosaic backroom docudrama ...
Agnès Varda, in the glory of her golden years, has become a humanist magician.
Abel Ferrara directs a documentary about his rock & roll band, but Ferrara the aging bad-boy legend deserves a better movie.
I count myself as a Coppola believer, but this may be the first film she has made in which her essential personality as a director gets buried under the movie she's making.

As a filmmaker, Baker is a graceful neorealist voyeur who thrives on improvisation, and his storytelling, in The Florida Project, is mostly just a series of anecdotes. But that turns out to be enough.
Takes up residence in your mental jukebox in a way that's so haunting, for a while it crowds out all the other beauty you've heard.
Stupidly entertaining...for a while.
Ostlund, at his best, is a heady and enthralling filmmaker, but unfortunately, he has so much on his mind that he is also, at his weakest, a shapeless and didactic one.
A lightly audacious and fascinating movie (if not exactly one to warm your heart) ...

It's a portrait of Kubrick's right-hand man, who devoted himself to the religion of all things Kubrick, but beyond that the film has a special value: It ushers you into the world of how Kubrick put his movies together.

The film enunciates its raw themes - punk means individuality! the aliens are all about conformity! - but never begins to figure out how to embody those themes in a narrative that could lure in the audience.
movie_title: How to Talk to Girls at Parties (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Takes an ominous, reverberating look not at the politics of Russia but at the crisis of empathy at the culture's core.
An ambitious doohickey impersonating a work of art.
The movie is a close-quarters psychological thriller built artfully and honestly, from the ground up, with more of a nod to early John Carpenter than mid-period Danny Boyle.
Lively, fun, sickening, and essential.
A passionate and beguiling movie-love documentary that shines a light on two of the unsung artisan heroes of Hollywood.
movie_title: Harold And Lillian: A Hollywood Love Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An aggressively cartoonish mother-daughter vacation-from-hell comedy that never strays far from the fractious, one-note surface.
Mamet has a quick, spry reaction time and a gently forlorn focus that holds the screen, and she holds this movie together.

"Hell on Earth" portrays the Syrian citizens, who live in a morass of civil war, with an emotional directness we can't turn away from, to the point that it's no longer possible to think of those citizens as "them." They are us, or could be.
movie_title: Hell on Earth: The Fall of Syria and the Rise of ISIS (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It sees Jeffrey Dahmer for what he was: a young man who could express himself only through the most hideous violence. Yet it shows you that what he had to express was real.
The surprise is that Skull Island isn't just ten times as good as Jurassic World; it's a rousing and smartly crafted primordial-beastie spectacular.
A Hallmark-card therapy session, a kind of woodland weekend-retreat self-actualization seminar hosted by the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost.
The strangers-at-a-table concept turns out to be a thin excuse to cobble together what might have been the pilot episode for a glibly forgettable TV series.
Robespierre still needs to fine-tune her skills as a storyteller, but scene for scene she has the right audacity - the honest kind - to explore that kind of experience.
Winning and impassioned, stirring and proudly wonkish ...
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It can't help but come off as a bit diagrammed. Yet the movie is onto something: what happens to a society when "ordinary" life begins to get stripped away.
"Sleepless" is a propulsive thin exercise, "energetic" but tedious, the kind of January movie that Jamie Foxx should have permanently graduated from.
Even when it seems to be making things up as it goes along, its slapdash hallucinatory quality is a token gesture toward placing you inside the characters' heads.
Should satisfy fans of the "Underworld" movies just enough to live up to the previous films' success ... and to guarantee that Beckinsale, if she so chooses, can ride out this saga some more.
"Bright Lights" captures the essence of what they had together - not just a bond but a mother-daughter marriage. One that lasted two lifetimes.
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Within that tight-lipped mask, [Khan] finds a hundred ways to communicate emotion. That's more than you can say for Dangal, a one-trick domestic sports drama that drags on for two hours and 40 minutes.
It's like seeing the ghost of a terrific movie: All the pieces are in place, yet as you're watching it (or thinking back on it afterwards), there doesn't seem to be quite enough there there.
In "Assassin's Creed," Michael Fassbender is like the ultimate special effect. Just by showing up, he confers respectability on two hours of semi-coherent overly art-directed video-game sludge.

"Passengers" is the tale of a lonely guy in space, the drama of an ethical conundrum, a love story featuring two of the hottest actors on the planet, and a turbulent sci-fi action-adventure - and for all of that, it manages to be not a very good movie.
A strenuously uplifting Christmas awards-bait tearjerker.
It's bluntly cheeky, it goes on for too long, but the concept keeps on giving.
You watch it thinking: There's a reason why Tracy and Hepburn movies never hinged on therapy, and didn't feature actors whose exteriors looked a lot more exciting than their inner lives.
Michael Shannon and Imogen Poots are terrific in a canny little neo-noir that takes an authentic look at the dark side of love.
A dutiful and diverting but rather bare-bones documentary portrait ...
As you watch "Fences," there's never a doubt that these lives matter, and that's a good and noble thing, but you're also aware (maybe too aware) of how much the movie itself wants to matter.
It's a flagrantly movie-ish concoction. But like Steven Spielberg's "Bridge of Spies," it's been made with a so-old-it's-new classicism that is executed with enough flair to lure audiences in.

"Best Worst Thing That Ever Could Have Happened" illustrates an essential principle of art: You have to risk cataclysmic failure - and, at times, fall into it - if you're planning to scale the heights.
movie_title: Best Worst Thing That Ever Could Have Happened... (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The movie assumes that a chronicle of Magnus's rise will be enough to keep the audience hooked. That turns out to be the right call.
A fascinating documentary captures the showdown, half a century ago, between the activist Jane Jacobs and the Trumpian urban planner Robert Moses: a fight for the future of New York.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A bad Christmas movie can give off all the warmth of a televised yule log, but David E. Talbert, the writer-director of "Almost Christmas," has assembled a gifted cast and given them a chance to stretch out and play with their roles.
A World War II epic about the cruiser that carried the A-bomb, and was disastrously torpedoed, never finds its dramatic life.
You may wonder what a fresh look at the events could possibly add to our knowledge. The answer turns out to be a great deal.
In almost every crucial way, "The Yellow Birds" is a flat and listless piece of moviemaking, a monotonous indie dirge that will probably end up fighting hard to win even a tiny audience.
Sheridan wants us to know these people, this terrain, to feel the bite of the cold and the lonely sting of their lives.
Harrelson brings his wide-awake edge to this performance, yet "Wilson" is a soft-headed comedy.
The analog pace and elemental story work for it. Each time the violence explodes, it's slashingly satisfying, because it's earned, and also because Mangold knows just how to stage it.
"Return to Montauk" is Volker Schlöndorff's tasteful, high-minded Euro-literate version of a Lifetime Movie - and I mean that (mostly) as a compliment.
Tame, competent, mildly touching, and a little dull - except for Catherine Deneuve's fearless turn as a boozing, ailing wreck.
"The Other Side of Hope" wants to take you back to a time when quirkiness in cinema felt not cute but bold. Apart from the songs, though, it just feels cute now. If that.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The maverick director Sabu has made a hitman fable that's like Charlie Chaplin meets Takeshi Miike. The weird thing is, it works.
It's dutiful, but it's also superficial and polite, and it commits the genteel sin of the old biopics: It turns its hero into a plaster saint.
movie_title: The Young Karl Marx (Le jeune Karl Marx) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: "Erase and Forget" is an inadequate documentary.
The movie is murky and disjointed, held together not so much by what happens as by a vague atmosphere of obsession.
A scrappy testament to the true nature of the Vladimir Putin regime.
movie_title: The Trial: The State of Russia vs Oleg Sentsov (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In "Final Portrait," Stanley Tucci, directing his first film in 10 years, takes the biopic to an even more exquisitely homespun level of miniature close-up.
Richard Gere, Laura Linney, Steve Coogan, and Rebecca Hall make a riveting quartet in Oren Moverman's adaptation of the Herman Koch novel about a dark-hearted dinner gathering.
"Cars 3" is very much a tale of mentorship, of learning how to give up your ego in order to bolster someone else's. As such, it's touching in a pleasingly formulaic, pass-the-torch way.
Did you ever think you'd shed a tear for dying coral?

Ford's intent as a filmmaker isn't just to expose and protest the injustice of his brother's murder. It's to say: Behold what was lost. A life. A human being. A complex soul. A family's equilibrium. Feel what was lost.
It's now the file-share that kills. I don't know why that's less threatening, but it is, kind of like seeing your favorite album cover reduced to a digital postage stamp.
The strength, and fascination, of "The Force" is that the movie isn't on anyone's side.
A skillful and ironically gripping coming-of-age movie: a hip-hop anti-biopic.
A sharp, fun, disquieting, and fleetly edited chronicle of the entire campaign year, inside and outside the media bubble, with the focus held obsessively on Donald Trump's rise.
movie_title: Trumped: Inside the Greatest Political Upset of All Time (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a watchable curio, because beneath it all the director, the Panamanian-born Janicza Bravo, has a more conventional sensibility than she lets on.
MacLaine has something that shines through and elevates a film like this one. The movie is prefab indie whimsy, but she gives it an afterglow.
A small-scale but elegantly deft squirmfest that features a luminous performance by Salma Hayek.
For a long time now, Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho" has been two movies, and the hypnotic film-geek documentary "78/52" is an ingenious and irreverent master class in both of them.
The great strength of "The New Radical" is that it's not on its subjects' side (or totally against them either). It's the rare documentary that lets you decide.
"Newness" explores the lures - and pitfalls - of an open relationship in the new culture of the digital meat market, but really, it's bringing some very old news.
Your average Pixar comedy thumbs its nose at a great many things, but "The Lego Batman Movie" is a helter-skelter lampoon in the daftly exhilarating spirit of Mad magazine and the "Naked Gun" films.
The best thing about "Rough Night" is the feisty, claws-out spontaneity of its competitive banter between "sisters" who love and hate each other.
The film's muted yet still rather flamboyant terribleness derives from the fact that it seems to be juggling three or four borderline schlock genres at once.
[A] messy, hugely flawed, but fascinating biographical drama ...
Dano, it's immediately clear, is a natural-born filmmaker, with an eye for elegant spare compositions that refrain from being too showy; they rarely get in the way of the story he's telling.
A heady lesson in how fake news really works - and how far back it stretches.
"Juliet, Naked" is a gently winning romantic comedy, all keyed to a delightful note of indie-rock obsession.
Most of this stuff is sharply, at times squeamishly, funny, though the laughter also catches in our throats, since "Private Life" is built around a core of heartbreak.
By the end, you're reminded, once again, why there are so many Michael Mann imitators but so few who are able to burn his influence into something memorable.
On its own terms, the film is watchable enough, but it's blunt and stolid and under-characterized, and at 130 minutes it plods.
Henson holds it together and, at moments, comes close to convincing you that you're watching a better movie.
Shephard has a lively eye for the neurotic ripples of high-school society, but her most audacious gambit is to dare to place the audience in a grey zone between innocence and judgment ...
A limply spritzing fountain of unconvincing (and unfunny) tricks out of the how-to-write-a-comedy-hit manual.
"The Greatest Showman" wants to give you a splashy good time, and does, and it's got something that takes you by surprise: a genuine romantic spirit.
The movie is bubbly, it's fast, it's hella synthetic-clever, and it's an avid showcase for the personalities of its stars ...
It's supposed to be a video-ized board game come to life, but really, it's just a bored game.

Not that it's awful, exactly. It's a low-budget generic shrug of a movie, one that recycles clichés both ancient (testy drug dealers) and slightly less ancient (the hero films his life with a camcorder).
"Phantom Thread" is seductive and absorbing, but it's also emotionally remote.
Pulses ahead like a detective yarn for news junkies, one that crackles with present-day parallels.
The movie meditates on what murder is by looking, more fully than most movies do, at the legacy of its aftershocks.
Watching "12th and Clairmount," you feel the anger of the riot alive in the inferno. It's the burning down of dreams.
It's a tasty franchise delivery system that kicks a certain series back into gear.

It's a very tasteful heart-tugger - a drama of disarmingly level-headed empathy that glides along with wit, assurance, and grace, and has something touching and resonant to say about the current climate of American bullying.
A boisterously formulaic and designed-by-committee holiday comedy ...

"The Last Five Years" filters the twilight of Bowie's career through the prism of an era when he reigned as pop royalty, and what you perceive now, far more than the fashion-forward evolutions, is the dazzling continuity beneath them.
movie_title: David Bowie: The Last Five Years (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You may or may not walk away from "Gilbert" a Gilbert Gottfried fan, but either way the movie makes you glad he exists.
In its fevered low-budget way it's just clever enough to do what it sets out to do. It gives toxic masculinity its just desserts.
A documentary that's sharp-edged, humane, and deeply researched enough to take you closer to the manic engine of Williams' brilliance and pain than you were before ...
movie_title: Robin Williams: Come Inside My Mind (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Lively, confessional, and entertaining ...
The daring of Ethan Hawke as a filmmaker is that he shapes his scenes not in a conventional way but as randomly observed slivers of life that amble and glide along to Blaze's dawdling spirit.
For those of us who never went (and probably couldn't have gotten in if we tried), "Studio 54" lets you taste a bit of the ecstasy.
Soul Surfer, while formulaic in design, is an authentic and heartfelt movie.
It's an accomplished and intermittently hypnotic movie. Yet you may feel like you're occupied more than you are invested.
"Blockers" isn't really about these girls losing their virginity. It's about how they seize control of their destinies, one triumphantly lewd zinger at a time.
Sometimes, getting on the clever/whatever wavelength of a horror film and just rolling with can be a part of the fun. "A Quiet Place" is that kind of movie.
There's no real terror or dread in it, just the same old meat-puppet gore and cattle-prod scares served up with a kind of ritualized self-satisfaction.
An impeccably made story-of-a-siege documentary that shows you how a revolution evolves, step by step, into a collective writhing being.
movie_title: Breaking Point: The War for Democracy in Ukraine (2018)

movie_review_blurb: "Death Wish," make no mistake, is a movie that has its heart in the wrong place.
By making a none-too-convincing femme fatale the source of its drama, "Submission" comes off as an antiquated and rather reactionary campus parable.
Lommel, as a filmmaker, never could separate his good ideas from his trendy and downright wretched ones.

At heart, "Every Day" is just an elaborately convoluted parable of a high-school girl learning to prize a savvy nice guy over a popular cad. But the movie demonstrates why that simple lesson is more than skin-deep.
If Game Night were just a concoction, it might grow tiresome awfully fast. There's a nagging speck of humanity, or at least reasonably quick and cutting marital satire, that keeps the movie afloat.
What's ultimately moving about "Along for the Ride" is that it communicates how Dennis Hopper, by sticking true to his reckless muse, was an artist who changed things, and maybe changed everything.
Elegantly tense and absorbing.
"Basmati Blues" is one of those movies that isn't terrible but still leaves you wondering why it exists.
The more we get to know him, the more his core motivation - is he an idealist or something else? - becomes the mystery of the film.

The film keeps telling us that what happened aboard that train was the fulfillment of something, but neither the event nor the three actors re-enacting it seem completely real. They seem like pieces of reality trapped in a movie.
Here's what it looks like when a routine bad movie goes off its rocker.
Sarah may not be crazy, but the film seems slightly nuts.
The movie humanizes King, in occasionally startling ways.
"Hal" has a once-over-lightly quality, but at times it offers a telling window into how the New Hollywood worked.
"Tully" has its heart (and many other things) in the right place, but by the end you wish it had an imagination finely executed enough to match its empathy.
The only aspect of it that I found I could focus on with even a modicum of interest was Will Forte's sideburns.
Collette's performance is staggering. She plays Annie as a woman who begins to wear her buried rage and guilt on the outside.
"Damsel" is a comedy of attitude made with the indulgent touch of an art Western. That's a refreshingly original thing, though it's not as blow-you-away cool as the filmmakers seem to think it is.
A distinctly inferior 3D IMAX film, an oversize tease of a sonic-adventure documentary that leaves you hollow rather than bedazzled.
Even if you belong to the choir it's preaching to, it has the rare distinction of being a movie you can agree and argue with at the same time.
movie_title: All Governments Lie: Truth, Deception, and the Spirit of I.F. Stone (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The new film, while just okay enough to get by, takes a step back from the audacity of "Bad Moms" to something more cautiously conventional.
The "Saw" genre was originally dubbed "torture porn." But at this point a more accurate description might just be "overkill."

"The Private Life of a Modern Woman" is a thrift-shop psychological X-ray that demands to be taken on its own Tobackian terms. But even on those terms, it spends too much time telling us things that it should be showing us.
movie_title: The Private Life of a Modern Woman (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner" served with mango chutney.
A lightly sneaky and entertaining movie.
In "First Reformed," Paul Schrader courts respectability and leaves it in the dust, getting stoned on excess. But make no mistake: He's still one hell of a filmmaker.
"Nico, 1988" ... understands the mystique of her anti-mystique, and deserves to attract a small but fascinated audience on the specialty circuit.
The most whimsically outlandish film of Payne's career, though that doesn't mean it's made with anything less than his usual highly thought-out and controlled master-craftsman bravura.
The film is intriguing on the surface, but the scenes have no interior hum, because they haven't been conceived psychologically.
A quaintly ingenious meditation on what the digital era is doing to us - how it has taken us a step away from reality, even as it's made everything easier.
At certain points in the middle of it, you may think "I'm miserable now," though not in the way that Morrissey had in mind.
As an animated entertainment, "The Nut Job 2" lacks several key factors: memorable characters, a fun story, jokes that will appeal to adults as well as little kids.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You want the chance to bask in his presence and come out with a heightened sense of what he's about. "The Last Dalai Lama?" accomplishes that, and with an offhand eloquence, though it's a sketchy, catch-as-catch-can movie ...
A wry tale that deserves to be seen.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a highly competent and watchable paranoid metaphysical video game that doesn't overstay its welcome, includes some luridly entertaining visual effects, and -- it has to be said -- summons an emotional impact of close to zero.
There have been worse ideas, but in this case the execution isn't good enough to bring the notion of an emoji movie to funky, surprising life.
Steven Soderbergh's Logan Lucky is a high-spirited, low-down blast.
A drama as powerful as it is timely.

It's a glib and scattered exposé, the sort of ersatz thesis film that invites you to chuckle at the sight of Reagan doing multiple takes of a campaign commercial while flubbing the name "Sununu" over and over again.
"The House," like too many Hollywood comedies of outrage, turns the extreme into the innocuous.
The appeal of this particular Spider-Boy is all too basic: In his lunge for valor, he keeps falling, and he keeps getting up.
The true magic that "Dawson City" captures is, simply, the mystery of film itself: a medium that turned people into shadows that burned brighter than life.

What the film offers is evidence of a pattern, the shadows of a disturbing trend that add up to a warning: If we, as a society, don't push back against the chipping away of the freedom of information, it's only going to get worse, until it eats us alive.
movie_title: Nobody Speak: Trials of the Free Press (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For the first time, the messy hyperactive form and nihilistic crunched-metal content seem to reinforce each other.
Each elegantly framed shot, every deftly observed moment expresses something organic and moving.
It's far from a masterpiece, yet it holds you, it adds up, and it's something to see.
It's the rare movie that truly evokes the grindhouse '70s, because it means everything it's doing. It's exploitation made with vicious sincerity.
By all means, go to "mother!" and enjoy its roller-coaster-of-weird exhibitionism. But be afraid, very afraid, only if you're hoping to see a movie that's as honestly disquieting as it is showy.
It seems more than a trifle obnoxious to tell a story that unfolds in a bubble of Hollywood privilege and to present it as if it were something that everyone could relate to.
Most of it is avid and surprising, and honestly moving, because the film refuses to hype what it shows you.
By the time it's over, you see the old conflicts with new eyes.
Even if you're just looking for a Tyler Perry night out, be very afraid.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo 2! A Madea Halloween (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A documentary that's incisive and haunting, like Didion's best writing.
movie_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's got movement and flow, it's got a vibrant sunset look of honky-tonk nostalgia, and it's got a bittersweet mood of lyrical despair that the film stays true to right up until the final note.
"Happy Death Day" is "Groundhog Day" dipped in blood, and if the movie isn't all that clever, it's just clever enough to get by.
With its penetrating look at a career that now spans half a century, "Spielberg" enriches a series of films that you - or, at least, some of us - never get tired of thinking about.

"Voyeur" leaves you intrigued but not fully satisfied. There's a third voyeur here: the movie itself. It keeps staring, trying to make sense of the bizarre tale it shows us, but it never quite breaks through the glass and touches it.
"Literally, Right Before Aaron" is minor - a spiky indie trifle - but it has a convincing perversity and flair.
In a strange way, the movie, as doggedly made as it is, remains stubbornly uncompelling.
The central reason that "Last Flag Flying" fails to take wing is that its characters don't ring true. Not really. You never feel, in your bones, that you're watching battle-scarred veterans.
"Frank Serpico" is a finely etched and fascinating documentary.
Whether or not you believe in the Devil, the film helps to color in how our culture got possessed.
It's subtle and absorbing, visualized with a sophisticated gloom that stays with you.
Even two glamorous and well-matched stars of the moment can't do much to undermine the Wenders meander.
"I Love You, Daddy" deserves a distributor, and its sharp dialogue and terrific cast should be a magnet for C.K.'s fans.
Roman is a fantastic character, and Washington's high-wire performance is one of his most daring and compelling.
"Chappaquiddick" is exactly what you want it to be: a tense, scrupulous, absorbingly precise and authentic piece of history - a tabloid scandal attached to a smoke-filled-room travesty.
Gaga radiates a potent energy - she's intensely funny and aware, and so unabashedly focused on herself that, like Madonna back in the day, that's simply who she is and who we want her to be.
A fresh, chancy, and wickedly enjoyable movie.
The whole thing becomes drenched in a kind of downbeat sentimental martyrdom that feels oppressively old-fashioned and moribund.
movie_title: The Racer and the Jailbird (Le Fidèle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: What might, theoretically, have been "All the President's Men" told from a reverse angle feels more like a prosaically engrossing TV-movie that whets your appetite for a more definitive treatment of the subject.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a lyrical and rapturous film - a repressed passion play, funny, delicate and heartbreaking.
"Jim & Andy" is fleetly edited and engrossing, animated by a sense of discovery.
movie_title: Jim & Andy: The Great Beyond - Featuring a Very Special, Contractually Obligated Mention of Tony Clifton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: "Super Size Me 2" is half a good movie, because it teaches you something. But maybe not enough. Spurlock, as instrumental as he has been in putting these issues on the table, doesn't seem to fully get what his own movie is about.
There are moments when the movie tugs at your heart, but the subject matter, because it's so epic, deserves an even more probing and definitive treatment.
The movie makes a good point, then makes it over and over again.

The phrase "low-budget horror" once held out the promise of seedy grisly sensation that big-budget horror wouldn't give you. But in the case of a movie like "The Unspoken," it just means: standard glossy horror tropes executed with scary ineptitude.
Farahani's direction is artfully suggestive but also, at moments, oblique; she seems to think that she's making a Godardian essay-film.
The film keeps you riveted, yet its achievement is finally more humanistic than cinematic.
A movie that conducts the crackling electricity of Brown's music with a heat and swagger and verve that rivals the achievement of what Taylor Hackford's Ray brought off 10 years ago.
Magic in the Moonlight is Allen's most gratifyingly airy concoction in a while, but it's also a comedy that insists, in the end, on making an overly rational case for the power of the irrational.
A notch more watchable than Volume I.
A spooky, heartbreaking documentary about Tanny le Clercq.
movie_title: Afternoon of a Faun: Tanaquil Le Clercq (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This moral-economic drama plays out in backroom deals that Boynton records in all their stunning and at times shameless candor.
It should have been made 40 years ago, but this biopic about the Mexican-American leader who spearheaded the fight for farmworkers' rights couldn't be more timely.
The finest rock doc since Anvil: The Story of Anvil.
The film's message seems to be that in corrupt governments, words are used not to communicate but as a kind of fascist confetti.
The real amazement of Dom Hemingway is that, as written and directed by Richard Shepard, the movie picks up this snarling hooligan and treats him like a character out of Shakespeare.
Captain America: The Winter Soldier is the first superhero film since the terrorist-inflected The Dark Knight that plugs you right into what's happening now.
The film captures how Pol Pot took Mao's Great Leap Forward to new levels of Marxist madness.
Director Matt Wolf uses startling archival footage to capture the rise of pre-Elvis youth culture as the defining surge of the 20th century.
Woodley, at every turn, lets us feel as if we're in her shoes, not so much Dauntless as thrillingly daunted.
Bateman deserves props for sustaining Bad Words as a little balancing act between sulfurously funny hatred and humanity.
The film gets us to see, in a new way, the strengths and weaknesses of weekly series television that viewers too often take for granted.
Back in his day, Mr. Peabody was a dog whose over-civility had bite. Now he's a genius you want to cuddle with.
I've had my Wes Anderson breakthrough - or maybe it's that he's had his. The Grand Budapest Hotel is a marvelous contraption, a wheels-within-wheels thriller that's pure oxygenated movie play.
The movie never finds a way to blend the emotional and the rat-a-tat-tat into one seamless package the way that Besson did in his one and only good movie, The Professional.
Pompeii, the new historical-kitsch disaster movie, raises the question: Is there something about ancient classical settings that inspires actors to act badly?

On paper, About Last Night is a third-generation copy of David Mamet's 1974 stage play Sexual Perversity in Chicago -- but if anything... it comes closer to Mamet's rancorous vision of dueling hormones than the '80s screen version did.

The film has lots of energized mayhem, and Murphy's unraveling of the conspiracy against him isn't dumbed down, yet it's as if the comic-book action poetry of the original has been encased in a suit of generic armor.
The Judge is like the soggiest Oscar nominee for best picture of 1982, but though few would confuse it with art, the film is deftly acted, and it holds you, it gets to you.
The audience at the premiere screening where I saw St Vincent responded on Pavlovian cue to the film's cutesy, aging-rebel theatrics, but, really, Bill Murray deserves a better movie.
An audacious little indie ... Hungry Hearts starts off innocently but becomes a new kind of psychodramatic indie thriller, a Rosemary's Baby in which the mother is her own demon.
While We're Young is a mostly enjoyable movie, but what it's trying for is wisdom, and that's a quality that Baumbach doesn't earn.
Moore has always been a guerrilla filmmaker, but in Where to Invade Next, his provocations dig deep below the surface of politics. He has made an act of guerrilla humanity.

A light subversion of today's blockbuster aesthetics... Trank isn't using characters with built-in visual spectacle to wow us. He's inviting us to react with sympathy to what is basically the bodily horror of their new abilities.
The zombie-horror-film title is the most dramatic feature of this meandering combat melodrama.

The film isn't terrible but it makes earlier Marvel outings look like masterpieces. There's hardly a trope in it you haven't seen before, and done with far greater flair. It feels like making a mountain out of an anthill.

Magic Mike XXL is the opposite of prudish, to the point that there's almost nothing at stake. And when they finally perform at the stripper convention, it looks like an off night at the MTV Video Music Awards.

Going Clear unpeels Scientology layer by layer via testimony from former high-level Church officials who have never spoken up before. The result is the most exciting - and disturbing - work of cinematic non-fiction in a long time.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's the audience that's being programmed [here] ... Blomkamp is an outrageously derivative filmmaker, but District 9 is a paragon of originality next to Chappie.
The Wachowskis' vision has turned out to be kitsch: reheated tales of good v evil and interplanetary conflict, all dressed up in HR Giger-meets-RuPaul couture.
Directed with confidence by Ava DuVernay, it's a movie about how King changed America by having the canny political genius to show the country an image of itself that it could not bear.
[A] feisty portrait of the musical-theater legend.
As played by Hutcherson, [Peeta] has all the charisma of the least interesting member of the Yale crew team. Three movies in, [his bond with Katniss appears] more desperately theoretical than ever.

If the movie works at all (and I think it does), it's as a swoony love story threatened by a basic, cornball Oedipal drama. But for a film that's coming out on Valentine's Day, that more than passed as respectable.
Welcome to the head-spinning gamesmanship of the Obama era - and to the most elegantly candid comedy of racial tension since Spike Lee burst onto the scene 30 years ago.
Eleanor Rigby isn't Scenes From a Marriage meets Rashomon - it's more like Before Midnight turned into a listlessly melancholy TV miniseries.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Inherent Vice has a dazzling and often entertaining atmosphere of debasement, like a smiley face rotting from the inside. Yet there's a real limit to its pleasure.
Whiplash is the second feature written and directed by Damien Chazelle, who expanded it out of a short that played at Sundance last year, and he's a true discovery.
You could call this vision misogynistic, and you wouldn't be wrong, but you'd be far more accurate if you simply called it ludicrous.
This is acting out of the My Left Foot handbook, except ... Redmayne rarely deviates from Hawking's whimsical quizzicality. It's a less wrenching, more user-friendly tour de force.
This is a very clandestine way to make a liberal message movie, but it works. You could almost say that it serves up Oscar bait in code.
You feel like you're right there in the studio with Brian Wilson as he creates Pet Sounds. It's a little like sitting next to Beethoven: the film is tender and moving, but also awe-inspiring.

Bennett Miller has made what might almost be called an awards-bait exploitation film, except that he purges the material of sensationalism, and he does so in the most honest and artful way possible. He keeps it real.
One of the most incisive movies about the post-9/11 world ever made.
Sandler gets lost in The Cobbler, and so does any vestige of the filmmaker's connection to his audience.

Reitman is such a skillful filmmaker that he doesn't just score didactic points. He's made the first movie to capture the tone, the rhythm, the flavour of our experience as it comes filtered through technology.
In the end, there isn't that much to the movie apart from what Snowden has to say. Fortunately, that proves to be enough.
The Martian is like Gravity without the floating, Apollo 13 without the documentary intrigue and 127 Hours without the mental breakdown. It's not nearly as exciting as you wished it was.
The Monuments Men sounds like a what's-not-to-like? movie, but it turns out to be a bizarre failure. It's not just that the film is dull - it's that there's no there there to like.
The film has that deadpan Linklater tone of slacker haphazardness, but you could also say that it's almost Joycean in its appreciation of the scruffy magic of everyday life.
Gurira acts with fire and pride and, at times, a despair bordering on instability.
Metallica, those thrash virtuosos of doom, get the grand 3-D opera they deserve: a godless-apocalypse-meets-Vegas spectacle, full of fireballs and electric chairs.
Robert Reich, a secretary of labor under President Clinton, leads us through a sharp-eyed essay-meditation on the rising trend of income inequality.
Gordon-Levitt proves a natural filmmaker, nimbly staging Jon's highly amusing Catholic confessions, along with porn montages that mimic the dopamine-charged editing of Requiem for a Dream.
Baggage Claim is almost masochistically cheesy, with zero surprise. But Patton glides through it like Jennifer Aniston with a touch of Audrey Hepburn.
A mesmerizing documentary trip to hell.
The movie sucks the audience into the power of the confessions, then shows us what really happened.
He has made a movie that the Louis Malle of Lacombe, Lucien, or the Truffaut of The 400 Blows, would have appreciated, an explicit look at how our humanity gets lost.
This is a movie made not with obligatory biopic beats but with verve and freedom, and offhand, I can't think of a better way to honor the genius of Hendrix
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: I'm glad, I seriously am, that John Carney wants to make deeply and embarrassingly sincere musical movies, and I hope he keeps on making them, but let's also hope he realizes that when it comes to Once, once was enough.
12 Years a Slave is a movie about a life that gets taken away, and that's why it lets us touch what life is.
I'm all for sincerity in filmmaking, but the quality that has defined Reitman's best movies - Up in the Air, Juno, and Thank You For Smoking - is audacity, and he really needs to get that back.

What's astonishing about the film is its hypnotic seamlessness - the way that the director, Alfonso Cuarón, using special effects (and 3D) with a nearly poetic simplicity and command, places us right up there in space along with the people on screen.
The saga of Ali's refusal to be drafted during Vietnam becomes a profile in courage -- a tale of shocking vilification and faith lost and found.
It's rooted in 40 years of Hollywood revenge films, yet it also breaks audacious new ground.
Feverishly edgy and exciting.
Touchy Feely is minor, but these people are good company.
Adore has the distinction of featuring some of the most laughable dialogue in any movie this year.
As the sweetly amoral tattooed-goddess-for-hire, Temple does her wiliest acting yet.
It has a chillingly matter-of-fact cynicism that is very au courant.
Passion turns into vintage De Palma - which is to say, the film seems almost engineered to get you giggling at the extravagance of its absurdity.
The film, despite a few splendid fights, is a biohistorical muddle that never finds its center.
The situation has a built-in heartbreak, but Cretton doesn't milk it. Instead, he lets each character strike a note of lived-in reality that is rarely found on screen.
This sharp documentary tribute to Downey's bug-eyed, fulminating charisma - he was like a Nixon who'd let out his id - reveals the demons that drove him to fame, then dragged him down.
movie_title: Évocateur: The Morton Downey Jr. Movie (2013)

movie_review_blurb: [Barbara Sukowa] invests Arendt with a steely fury, but the film, set during and after the 1961 trial of ex--Nazi official Adolf Eichmann, has an entertaining cocktail-banter superficiality.
This episodic drama is set in Dallas during the three days after the JFK assassination, and some of it is highly charged.
The film has an accomplished mood of cantankerous despair, but it's still little more than downbeat fluff.
What does the movie version of Life Itself really have to show or tell us? A great deal, it turns out.
Costner is in fine dry form, Knightley is at her most open and gorgeous, and Pine goes through the motions of saving the Western world with a swaggery concentration that keeps you watching.
The movie is voyeuristic, sure, but in a way that evokes Alfred Hitchcock's Rear Window more than William Friedkin's Cruising.

An exquisitely fun documentary that hits on a profound aesthetic question, one first posed in 2001 by David Hockney: Did the 17th-century Dutch painter Johannes Vermeer use optical devices to achieve his visual poetics of light?
A wrenchingly intimate tale of lives torn asunder by forces within and without them.
Jessica Tandy and Morgan Freeman give exceptional performances
When a movie is based on a celebrated play, the first question to ask is, Does it play? In the case of August: Osage County... the answer is yes.
You can see, and hear, the clanking of his melodramatic machinery - the gears and pulleys of emotion - but by the time the movie is over, you've been wedged into those gears; they have you.
It's a film of jaw-dropping virtuosity and pleasure, one that leaves you revved, enthralled, tickled, moved, and amazed.
Jackson's direction is spiky and majestic ...
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Josh Brolin, with his loping physique and handsome, hangdog scowliness, is like Nick Nolte's volatile younger brother, and in Spike Lee's rivetingly intense Oldboy, he gives a terrific and harrowing performance as a slimeball out for justice.

It's fast and original, it's conceptually audacious, it's visually astonishing, and it's 10 times more clever and smart and funny than it needed to be. Here, at last, is an animated comedy that never stops surprising you.
Frozen is a squarely enchanting fairy tale that shows you how the definition of what's fresh in animation can shift.
The Best Man Holiday is an eggnog that's sticky-sweet and heavy at the same time.
The new film sprawls, often with more spirit than reason.
I steeled myself for the moment when these four would fall into what-happens-in-Vegas ''high jinks,'' but fortunately, they don't.

Gleeson and McAdams make a touching, lifelike couple, but by the time the movie starts telling us to live each day as if we were going back and doing it all over again, you may feel Curtis has mistaken hokum for wisdom.
You'll occasionally laugh out loud, but the heart of the movie is safe enough to chuckle at.
She blows stuff up real good, in a way that would make the devil - or Bruce Willis - proud.
This is only the second film by Chandor, and he works in a style of great purity. There's hardly a 'movieish' moment to speak of in All Is Lost.
Greengrass keeps you off balance - he's a jittery poet of reality.
Rodriguez's only real sin as a filmmaker is that he wants to give you way too much of a crazy ultraviolent good time.
As long as you're hearing the singing and stories of Lisa Fischer, Merry Clayton, and the great Darlene Love, you can bliss out on their passion.
Sin, more stylized than the director's previous work, is also more detached.
Catching Fire is more energized than the first Hunger Games movie; it's been directed, by Francis Lawrence, with a darkly sustained verve.
Russell plays Jane's scatterbrained romanticism with such underhanded charm that she goes a long way toward making the laughs seem pertly knowing, even when they come at Jane's expense.
Abraham hasn't done the basic work of interpreting Williams' life; he lays out the incidents as if he were dramatising a Wikipedia entry.

The Walk, while it could have used a better script, is a transporting experience, and the ultimate reason for that is that the Philippe Petit we see offers up his death-defying showmanship as an act of faith, not just for himself but for everyone.
If it is sometimes a rambling and indulgent experience, it's also a beautiful one.
For all of Martin Koolhoven's talent, a hifalutin exploitation picture like "Brimstone" has too much - and not enough - on its mind.
It immerses you in the violent madness of war - and, at the same time, it roots its drama in the impeccable valor of a man who, by his own grace, refuses to have anything to do with war.
Franco's first watchable dramatic feature.
Tom Ford's first film since 'A Single Man' is another winner, an ambitious high-wire noir thriller with Amy Adams and Jake Gyllenhaal in an explosive tale of love, violence, and revenge.
The most audacious big-screen musical in a long time, and - irony of ironies - that's because it's the most traditional.
"The Light Between Oceans" winds up taking one too many self-serious twists and turns. The film earns its darkness, but it might have been even more affecting if it didn't shrink from the light.
Instead of developing its themes, it uses them as grist for an overload of "commercial" action.

"Mechanic: Resurrection" is the movie "The Mechanic" should have been - a bite-sized Bond film, or maybe a grittier homicidal knockoff of the "Mission: Impossible" series, with a lone-wolf renegade as the entire team.
You wish this portrait of Japan's rice-wine elixir were half as intoxicating as its subject.
movie_title: Kampai! For the Love of Sake (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Ben-Hur" is an oddly lackluster affair: sludgy and plodding, photographed in nondescript medium close-up, an epic that feels like a mini-series served up in bits and pieces.
With the 'Hangover' trilogy behind him, director Todd Phillips has made his first terrific movie for grown-ups, starring Miles Teller and Jonah Hill in a true-life tale of hip-geek arms dealers.

"The Lost Arcade" is an engaging minor movie, but it touches on something that's being lost in the age of technology that's much bigger than video-game arcades: the feeling that there's a reason - driving and inescapable and romantic - to leave home.

Draper paints affecting thumbnail portraits of athletes like Ralph Metcalfe, a slightly older sprinter who became a role model for Owens, and Howell King, a boxer who... was forced, for no good reason, to do his qualifying bout a second time.
Spacey, who is known in showbiz circles for his wicked improvisations, could probably have made up wittier dialogue in his sleep. He's hamstrung by this glum paycheck dud, and so is everyone else.
A documentary portrait of the director of 'Boyhood' and 'Dazed and Confused' is full of revealing offscreen footage as well as a pinpoint feeling for the filmmaker's visionary humanism.
The laughter this movie offers could provide cathartic medicine for the middle-class mom blues.

The film offers a true immersion in his artistry. But it's also a little slipshod - an off-kilter window into the politics of the art world. It's like a fascinating magazine feature with some missing pieces.
movie_title: Hieronymus Bosch, Touched by the Devil (Jheronimus Bosch, Touched By The Devil) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Nerve," let's be clear, isn't a movie to take seriously, yet its fast lunge at topicality - the way it uses the contest at its center as a lightning-rod metaphor for how young adults interact in the digital age - is part of what's fun about it.
A whistleblowing documentary made with fearless guerrilla cunning ...
Frank, a wildly impressionistic filmmaker, shows a flair for taking the most lackadaisical of encounters and crafting them into something pungent and revealing.
Tim Kirkman's drama about two men who reunite after 15 years is so well-written and acted you feel like you're eavesdropping.
"Star Trek Beyond" is a somewhat diverting place holder, but one hopes that the next "Star Trek" movie will have what it takes to boldly go where no "Star Trek" movie has gone before.
Making a film that has the contemporary aspect of a planetarium show is, in its way, a deeply cool and populist thing to do, and "Voyage of Time" is likely to connect with audiences ...
It's a movie that follows every trope in the book, and does so with pleasing fireworks and finesse.
A meandering mess.
The film captures how the unreality of tabloid journalism has slid through digital portals into the mainstream, becoming part of the toxic air of misinformation that we all now breathe.
The movie is simply Lumet and his films, which turns out to be an astonishingly satisfying experience, because he's an incredible talker, with the same earthy electric push that powers his work.
It's another of Perry's raucous and slovenly comedies of responsibility, which means that its heart is in a very old - and right - place. If only a message that was this solid equalled solid laughs.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo! A Madea Halloween (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Michael Moore In TrumpLand" comes on with a bombs-away fury, but it winds up being a tossed hand grenade that doesn't fully detonate.
Earth to movie executives: This is not what Jon Hamm should be doing!

It makes no major dramatic missteps, yet it could have used an added dimension - something to make the two-hour-and-20-minute running time feel like a transformative journey rather than an epic anecdotal crusade.
The film isn't simply a technological experiment; it's also a highly original, heartfelt, and engrossing story. And part of the power of it lies in the way that those two things are connected.
A little of this is funny, but a lot of it raises the question: Why is the new king of comedy working so hard to grab and hold our attention? Is he secretly worried he's going to lose it?
Kids should adore it, but don't let that scare you - the movie is every 3D psychedelic inch a fairy tale for adults.
"20th Century Women" is an endless chain of anecdotes, and though many individual moments are winning, the movie as a whole is rudderless. It never achieves an emotional power surge.

The movie wants us to raise our fists and shout, "Yes, that's what happened. And it's an outrage!" Instead, you may feel like raising your hand and asking "Is that really what happened? If so, it's an outrage! Now please show us some evidence."

If you watch "I Am Not Your Negro," you'll spend a kaleidoscopic and transporting 90 minutes living inside James Baldwin's mind, coming thrillingly close to his existential perception of the hidden meaning of race in America.
A piece of ahistorical liberal-bashing that slides from propaganda to paranoia.
movie_title: Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As a big-screen thriller, "The Girl on a Train" is just so-so, but taken as 112 minutes of upscale psychodramatic confessional bad-behavior porn, it generates a voyeuristic zing that's sure to carry audiences along.
Much ado about nothing.

By the time "Generation Startup" is over, you feel like you've spent some quality time with people who incarnate both the unique opportunities offered to their generation and, in a certain unstated way, the lack of opportunities.
A strenuously unfunny animated comedy.
Steinfeld makes Nadine a hellion you can't tear yourself away from. She isn't just the star of "The Edge of Seventeen" - she's its center of gravity.
As a thief trying to break away from his criminal father, Michael Fassbender can't act his way out of this pile of grungy nonsense.
Reiner has been around the block enough times to relish everything in Johnson that's rudely incorrect.

The annoyance factor of "My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea" extends to the animation, which is remorselessly clever and original yet still oddly uninvolving; it's like being buried in a dump truck's worth of antic indie drollery.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The crucial thing missing is what should be the essence of a courtroom drama: our immersion in how Lipstadt's lawyers stake out their strategy.
Set in 1981, a canny and absorbing drama paints a highly convincing portrait of Barack Obama when he was a 20-year-old college student in New York, still piecing together who he was.
It's got a few chuckles, but mostly it plays like a rerun of past comic glories.

Stone's exile in the desert of overheated irrelevance has now ended. "Snowden" isn't just the director's most exciting work since "Nixon" (1995) - it's the most important and galvanizing political drama by an American filmmaker in years.

More than just another documentary, it's a crucial and stirring document - of racism and injustice, of politics and the big-picture design of America - that, I believe, will be watched and referenced for years to come.

Fukunaga, coming off his potent direction of the first season of HBO's True Detective, proves he is an artist who can work, with staggering skill, in the jittery, explosive tradition of movies like Oliver Stone's Salvador.
What makes this movie about a zombie attack different from any other movie about a zombie attack? Nothing but its ineptitude.
It's a bank-robbery thriller and a "political" exposé all at once: No wonder this overly elaborate potboiler turns into a muddle.
In "Paterson" the appeal of the Jarmusch vision shrinks down - in every way - to something relatively minimal.

The sort of cheerfully hostile buddy bash that's been a staple since the '80s, only this one is singularly clever about its own triviality, and it offers the scruffy pleasure of seeing two great actors dial down their gravitas with style.
[A] dourly aggressive, in-your-face thriller.

"I, Daniel Blake" is one of Loach's finest films, a drama of tender devastation that tells its story with an unblinking neorealist simplicity that goes right back to the plainspoken purity of Vittorio De Sica.

The technical bravura that Guiraudie summoned in "Stranger" - the subtle manipulation of light, weather, shot language, and temporal cunning - now falls by the wayside in a story that lurches from episode to disconnected episode.
The movie, watchable as it is, never quite overcomes the sense that it's a lavish diagram working hard to come off as a real movie.

By the time Holy Hell reaches its ominous final scene, the scariest thing about it is that Allen has made a movie about how he fell into a cult and then liberated himself from it, but at the end he still seems the tiniest bit under its spell.
Everybody Wants Some!! is about the moment when youth culture began to evolve into a cult of team players. It taps into how the freewheeling '70s gave way to a spirit of creeping conformism.
By the end, 10 Cloverfield Lane feels like a marketing plan posing as a movie.

Deadpool hooks you into Wade's trauma, but mostly it's content to skate along on the cheekiness of his death-sport attitude. The film's airy cynicism says: he's not the hero we dream of, he's just the one we deserve.
It's scrupulous and honorable, with moments of scalding power. But it's also just good enough to make me wish it had been better.

Goat rambles a bit, yet it's a wild, scary, fascinating, and humane portrait of a system of approved depravity that has had way too many young men in its grip, reprogramming them into their own worst enemies.

Jane Austen, who used dialogue as a veil that reveals and conceals, and writer-director Whit Stillman, with his love for the elegant pensée, are such an obvious match that you wonder why it took them this long to get together.
It's a crock, but a clever, halfway likable one. You can reject the way it plays you and still feel that you've been effectively played.
A movie called Michael Jackson's Journey that leaves out the personal dimension of his transformation is missing a key part of the story.
movie_title: Michael Jackson's Journey From Motown to Off the Wall (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most enticing aspects of this beautiful and clear-eyed doc is that the movie, while it makes the case for Mapplethorpe as a fearless and important artist, never denies that a number of his photographs were obscene.
A sluggish, unimaginative dud, brimming with venom but not much cleverness.
It has a furtive soulfulness that sneaks up on you. It's the real thing - a true romance - merged with a resonant riff on what might be called the metaphysics of tolerance.
It's bold, fleshy and audacious, at least in theory. But it is also numb.
If you want to know what the mathematical opposite of suspense looks like, take a look at Mockingjay - Part 2.
It's only 92 minutes long, but it draws the audience into a magisterial biography; it's electric, intimate and heartbreaking.
Tragedy, by nature, may be inevitable, but when the hand of fate is this heavy, there's simply too much gloom to go with the doom.

Steve Jobs is an exciting piece of iconoclasm: a talky, charged thriller for the brain that offers an intimate interpretation of who Jobs really was, even as it shrewdly undercuts many of the high-tech-saviour claims that have been made for him.
Alejandro Jodorowsky's 'Endless Poetry' is the most accessible movie he has ever made, and it may also be the best. It's Felliniesque and moving.

"Hell or High Water" is a thrillingly good movie - a crackerjack drama of crime, fear, and brotherly love set in a sun-roasted, deceptively sleepy West Texas that feels completely exotic for being so authentic.

Gets the job done, but it's hard to escape the feeling that you're watching a routinely conceived, rather generic boxing flick. It's utterly competent, yet it makes Duran's story seem a little so-what?

The audience looks at Niloofar and feels so connected to her eager vitality that we want her to be everything that she can be. But she's living in a society where that desire must take a back seat...to just about everything else.
Zac Efron and Aubrey Plaza lead a game cast in a gently nutty comedy that has a bit of cleverness to go with the raunch.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Bryan Cranston gets a film role worthy of his ability to break bad in a tensely exciting true-life drama of undercover drug agents.
"The Purge: Election Year" is a scurrilously effective pop rabble-rouser - a movie that's been built to get you riled, and does.
A scarily routine stalker thriller proves that just because you show a movie at midnight doesn't make it a midnight movie.
The madly teeming pop-cartoon paintings of Robert Cenedella anchor a lively look at a self-styled superstar of outsider art.

It's not necessary, of course, for "The Phenom" to be an all-out sports drama, but writer-director Noah Buschel sets up the rare opportunity to explore what makes a jock tick, then doesn't follow through.
It's like "Straw Dogs" as a mediocre TV-movie, and the tension slowly dissipates.
"Free State of Jones" is one of those historical dramas with a script that's big on crowning lines of moral fervor and not so big on nuts-and-bolts detail.
The long-running series returns to form with an infectious chatterbox comedy about the end of the world as we know it.
Henry Rollins' performance as a philosophical L.A. serial killer is the only reason to see this slipshod indie bank-hostage thriller.

It delivers - on some basic, giddy, turn-off-your-frontal-lobes level. It's an action-comedy utensil, like "Rush Hour" crossed with an old Arnold Schwarzenegger shoot-'em-up, with a few goofy added sprinkles of "Romy and Michele's High School Reunion."
Rescue-dog purists may not approve of the line "The Dog Lover" takes, yet to this dog lover it comes off as compassionate and realistic: a plea for a place where good care can become common sense.
An undead count seeks out the assistance of Sigmund Freud in a nudge-nudge Austrian monster comedy that's all anemic kitsch.
movie_title: Therapy for a Vampire (Der Vampir auf der Couch) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "The Music of Strangers" is an aural celebration that's about using the past to break free of boundaries.

A film that shapes and alters your perceptions.

It has a few amusing moments, but it's really a predigested one-joke comedy. It's less an honest satire than an overscaled satirical package.
A madly spinning top of a movie, powered by an eagerness to please that somehow comes off as more innocent than calculated.
"Blood Father" is trash, but it does capture what an accomplished and winning actor Mel Gibson can be. Just because he lost his bearings, and his career, doesn't mean that he lost his talent.

It's not boring, but there's less to it than meets the eyeball.

movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: O resultado é que este é, ao lado de Brilho Eterno de uma Mente Sem Lembranças, um dos melhores filmes do ano. E, também como aquele, um dos mais românticos.
Mesmo com todas as suas falhas, produz um número suficiente de surpresas narrativas que o situam acima da maior parte do lixo que Hollywood produziu em 2004.
Em um ano marcado por produções medíocres, Colateral acaba merecendo destaque - não por seus méritos, mas por eliminação.
Sua ótima qualidade técnica merecia ser aproveitada por um roteiro melhor.
Funciona não apenas como um suspense exemplar, mas principalmente como um estudo sobre a fragilidade do Homem diante da Natureza e sobre a maneira com que enxergamos a morte.
Não é um filme inovador, é verdade, mas foi competente o bastante para fazer com que eu me importasse com o destino do casal principal sem ficar entediado durante o processo.
Provavelmente já terá sido esquecido daqui a um ano - o que não quer dizer que não funcione como um passatempo divertido e descompromissado enquanto dura a projeção.
Esforça-se para parecer 'picante', mas não tem coragem sequer de exibir o corpo de sua protagonista.
A série Resident Evil também se transformou em um morto-vivo. E já está devorando os cérebros de seus espectadores.
Os resquícios da obra original de Asimov são o bastante para que possamos sair do cinema razoavelmente satisfeitos.
Investe muito em sua embalagem épica e pouco naquilo que deveria ser o mais importante: sua história e seus personagens.
Contando uma história engraçada e interessante, o longa continua a tratar as fábulas com irreverência.
Uma versão ruim e 'científica' (com enormes aspas) do superior Cemitério Maldito - o que já é o bastante para que você tenha uma idéia da dimensão do desastre.
A mocinha não precisava ser Ph.D em Dramaturgia, é claro, mas tampouco deveria ser retratada como alguém com Q.I. inferior ao de Forrest Gump.
Um filme ambicioso e maduro que, ao mesmo tempo em que impressiona com suas seqüências de ação, jamais deixa de lado o desenvolvimento de seus personagens.
A escala grandiosa dos cenários e das batalhas serve apenas para esconder a fragilidade do argumento.
Os realizadores não compreenderam a essência do material original: as tiras criadas por Davis giram em torno das atitudes de Garfield, e não de suas ações.
O diretor já revelou que um segundo filme, produzido apenas com as cenas deletadas deste, será incluído no DVD. Será que a pré-venda já começou?
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Esta atrocidade poderia representar um embaraço para todos os envolvidos, caso estes tivessem algum senso de ridículo - o que, a julgar por este longa, não parece ser o caso.
Afinal de contas, qual é o grande argumento de Spurlock? O de que comer sanduíches e batatas fritas em excesso provoca aumento de peso? Como diria Homer Simpson: 'Duh!'.
Levinson nunca foi um bom diretor de comédias (Bom Dia, Vietnã deve seu sucesso a Robin Williams), mas aqui ele definitivamente atinge o fundo do poço.
Revela-se corajoso ao levar o espectador a perceber que, depois de tantos esforços, Castle não alcança a paz de espírito que procurava.
O que tinha tudo para se transformar em um thriller psicológico de primeira acabou assumindo a forma de um filme B pouco inspirado.
Code 46 é o filme que O Dogma do Amor queria ter sido.
Em função de sua própria premissa, apresenta questões éticas interessantes.
Ao que parece, os realizadores de Mulheres Perfeitas acreditaram que o público seria tão dócil e manipulável quanto as esposas retratadas em sua trama.
Há o risco de que seus argumentos sejam atribuídos ao desprezo que Moore sente por Bush, quando, na realidade, são apenas uma questão de justiça e de bom senso.
Halle Berry parece estar numa daquelas aulas de teatro em que o professor insiste para que os alunos finjam ser árvores, nuvens ou bicicletas ergométricas.
muitos espectadores talvez julguem melhor economizar o dinheiro do ingresso do cinema, utilizando-o para comprar o CD do filme.
É uma pena que, gradualmente, deixe de ser um interessante estudo de personagem e se transforme em um drama tipicamente hollywoodiano.
Através de uma edição ligeira, procura nos convencer de que algo engraçado está acontecendo e que há uma dinâmica autêntica entre seus personagens. Não há e não está.
Os poucos momentos de maior inspiração não são suficientes para fazer jus à carreira de Sayles, às belas atuações de seu elenco e tampouco ao importante tema de seu filme.
Há dois bons filmes em Refém de uma Vida, mas estes se enfraquecem mutuamente em função da estrutura narrativa adotada pelo cineasta.
Payne leva o espectador a se envolver com figuras que, em produções menos ambiciosas, seriam retratadas como seres desagradáveis e repulsivos.
A performance (de Sean Penn) neste filme é mais um exemplo de sua genialidade.
Mar Adentro, assim como a própria vida de Sampedro, funciona principalmente para nos forçar a uma análise interior que pode revelar-se impiedosa e surpreendente.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Jamais gasta um minuto que seja para estabelecer melhor as motivações dos personagens.
Se esta comédia oferece algumas boas gargalhadas, todas se devem a Kevin James.
Condena a falta de respeito com que o jogador foi tratado no fim de sua vida, mas comete o mesmo erro ao destruir sua história em um filme profundamente equivocado.
Qualquer um que queira assista a O Amigo Oculto duas vezes vai perceber a falta de lógica do roteiro e... Ah. Entendi. Não há este risco.
Além não gerar tensão alguma no espectador, ainda torna-se enfadonho a partir de sua metade.
O roteiro impede que Constantine faça jus ao interessante personagem-título.
É um alívio constatar que ainda há realizadores que sabem utilizar a tecnologia não como um fim em si mesma, mas como mera ferramenta para dar vida à imaginação dos artistas.
O filme claramente ressente a ausência de Michael Caine. (...) Sandra Bullock é uma gracinha, mas não faz milagres.
Moreno é uma daquelas atrizes que prendem o olhar do espectador, que, fascinado, mal percebe o sutil trabalho de construção de personagem que está sendo desenvolvido.
O melhor aspecto do filme reside na maneira inteligente com que discute as implicações sociais e morais de sua premissa - a marca registrada de toda boa ficção científica.
Apresenta mais acertos do que erros.
Assim que a história parece prestes a se entregar a um clímax emocionante, o roteiro decide mergulhar no pior dos melodramas.
Mesmo pecando por ser convencional demais, este é um filme charmoso e bem-intencionado - e certamente fará grande sucesso entre as crianças.
Adotando uma estrutura narrativa deficiente, o longa conta com performances irregulares e é prejudicado por um roteiro desconexo que compromete o projeto.
É um bom filme, não há dúvida. Mas, com um pouco mais de coragem, poderia ter sido tão ambicioso quanto o próprio Peter Pan.
Uma produção triste e - sim - uma bela homenagem aos combatentes do fogo.
A pergunta é: você quer transformar o título brasileiro desta produção em realidade?
Scorsese conduz o filme com competência singular, mantendo a narrativa sempre focada e utilizando de forma fascinante as cores em cada uma das cenas.
Tem imenso potencial para se tornar um daqueles clássicos obrigatórios nas festas de fim de ano.
No mínimo, uns 30 minutos poderiam ter ficado no chão da sala de edição. Ou uns 60. Aliás, para ser mais exato, 98 minutos. Esta seria a única forma de salvar este projeto.
Se você ouvir alguém dizendo que se identificou com Bridget Jones, meu conselho é: rompa a amizade. Você não vai querer perder seu tempo com alguém assim.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Não posso deixar de pensar que seria ótimo se Chuky fosse estéril.
É irônico que alguns dos personagens mais complexos do ano tenham surgido não em uma produção estrelada por atores de carne-e-osso, mas sim por figuras criadas em computador.
Faltou-lhe coragem, mas não boas intenções.
Uma inteligente discussão sobre aceitação, fé e as conseqüências repugnantes do fundamentalismo religioso - tudo isto em uma embalagem divertida e irreverente.
É uma pena que esta tenha sido, provavelmente, a única incursão de Kitano pelo universo de Zatoichi. Seria bom ver o samurai cego mais vezes.
[Director] John Borowski lends an eerie atmosphere to the proceedings.
movie_title: H.H. Holmes - America's First Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Shimizu deveria ao menos corrigir os furos mais grotescos da trama - principalmente se considerarmos que vem trabalhando com o mesmo material há quase cinco anos.
Oliver Stone revela uma decepcionante tendência para o melodrama.
Nos permite observar a interação de quatro pessoas complexas e interessantes.
Aqui está um projeto que praticamente implorava para ser comandado por Tim Burton e estrelado por Johnny Depp.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Há uma linha tênue entre uma personagem complexa e outra mal-construída - e Elektra se encaixa nesta última categoria.
Se todo jovem ator tivesse uma estréia tão promissora na direção de longas, o Cinema norte-americano estaria bem melhor.
Se eu fosse descendente de Verne processaria os produtores desta adaptação pavorosa por mancharem o nome da família ao incluí-lo nos créditos iniciais.
A busca por concisão em uma cinebiografia é importante, mas não pode ser alcançada sacrificando-se a complexidade da história e tornando-a artificial, que é o que ocorre aqui.
Sombrio, complexo e instigante.
Em vez de corrigir os pontos fracos do filme original, inclui uma série de novos defeitos que comprometem irremediavelmente o resultado final.
Pena que a dupla de roteiristas não pôde realizar façanha semelhante à do herói e voltar no tempo a fim de rever suas decisões: o último ato do filme merecia uma nova chance.
Se precisei assistir a esta animação 3 vezes somente para escrever sobre ela, nem imagino quantas vezes voltarei a vê-la apenas pelo prazer de visitar a criação de Chomet.
A magistral performance de Daniel de Oliveira encontra-se (e este é o maior elogio que posso imaginar) no mesmo nível daquela oferecida por Val Kilmer em The Doors.
Representa uma importante lição de ética para os profissionais de Comunicação e deveria ser exibido em todos os cursos de Jornalismo.
Esperemos que seu sucesso nas bilheterias abra as portas para novos projetos protagonizados por atores veteranos. Quem sabe o filme não se redime desta maneira?
Algumas gags funcionam, mas numa razão de cerca de 30%, eu diria. Portanto, talvez esta produção valha o preço do ingresso - isto é, caso você consiga 70% de desconto.
Um filme forte e relevante.
É como se, envergonhado pela falta de integridade artística de John Logan, o próprio filme houvesse decidido praticar o haraquiri a 50 minutos do final da projeção.
Uma comédia de horror que não assusta nem faz rir.
Escola de Rock já havia acabado há mais de meia hora quando percebi que continuava a sorrir - um sinal inequívoco de que o filme funcionara maravilhosamente bem.

movie_title: Lavoura Arcaica (To the Left of the Father) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Theron, a princípio, parece uma espécie de 'Gollum de saias': sabemos que não estamos vendo algo real, mas não conseguimos deixar de acreditar em sua existência.
Seria ótimo se Allen passasse a dedicar mais tempo ao desenvolvimento de suas idéias. É melhor ver um bom filme a cada dois ou três anos do que sofrer uma decepção todo ano.
Podemos até admirar a engenhosidade do tal 'golpe perfeito', mas não nos importamos muito com seus resultados.
Triste e moralmente complexo, o filme se encaixa com perfeição no Grande Tema de 2003: o drama familiar.
Além de contar com as estupendas atuações de Winn e Pacino (em sua brilhante estréia no Cinema), este ainda é um dos melhores filmes já produzidos sobre dependência química.
Revolutions encerrou de maneira melancólica uma saga que teve início de forma inteligente e promissora.
Apesar de suas omissões, é um projeto inovador e interessante.
Não deixe de assistir a esta obra-prima. Não é sempre que o Cinema produz algo assim.
[O filme é] suficientemente inteligente para prender a atenção do espectador sem se tornar maniqueísta.
Assim como no programa de tevê, os 'Cassetas' insistem em usar, neste longa, o bordão 'Sacaneei!'. Infelizmente, eles sacanearam mesmo.
Um filme interessante, mas não muito eficiente.
Jamais deixa de ser envolvente, já que Curtis, um escritor experiente, é hábil na construção das histórias, que são recheadas com seu humor tipicamente britânico.
É um pouco difícil levá-lo a sério, já que sua postura de 'filme-denúncia' soa, no mínimo, anacrônica.
Um trabalho que não deveria ser visto apenas por meia dúzia de cinéfilos, mas que merecia ser adotado como experiência obrigatória em todos os colégios e faculdades do país.
Os animadores da Disney fazem mais um trabalho excepcional e repleto de preciosismos.
Um raro exemplo de filme que utiliza o sexo não como forma de atrair o interesse superficial do espectador, mas sim para desenvolver a relação entre seus personagens.
Não é um filme fácil de se assistir (tanto no aspecto emocional quanto intelectual), mas isso não quer dizer que não seja magnífico ao seu próprio - e melancólico - modo.
Com tantos recursos à sua disposição, este projeto poderia ter sido realmente memorável. Quem sabe Sandy e Júnior não acertam da próxima vez?
Por pouco não 'mata' Veronica Guerin pela segunda vez ao macular sua memória.
Uma lição de crescimento e otimismo que todas as crianças deveriam receber. Isto é, caso pudessem assistir a Bad Santa - algo que elas definitivamente não devem fazer.
É triste constatar que, a partir de agora, não mais teremos direito às nossas viagens anuais à Terra-média.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Confesso que ri ao perceber que daria 5 estrelas para este longa - mas qualquer outra cotação seria injusta e preconceituosa.
A grande tragédia do filme é que nenhuma daquelas pessoas é fundamentalmente má; elas apenas tomam decisões erradas que geram uma série de mudanças tristes em suas vidas.
Alfonso Cuarón imprime (ao filme) um aspecto sombrio, sem, com isto, perder a característica mais fascinante da série: o invencionismo de J.K. Rowling.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Ao tornar o espectador íntimo da tripulação do H.M.S. Surprise, Peter Weir confere uma dimensão adicional ao conflito.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Um videogame mal realizado.
Um filme medíocre que narra uma história batida e que merecia ter sido lançado diretamente em vídeo.
Prende a atenção do espectador graças aos seus interessantes personagens e ao rico universo no qual estes vivem.
Quote not available.
O filme não consegue sequer encontrar o tom apropriado para a narrativa.
Quote not available.
Além de utilizar as belas locações com a máxima eficiência, Salles também guia o espectador com segurança através da jornada interior de seus personagens.
Por favor, evitem que este filme alcance uma boa bilheteria e viabilize um Van Helsing 2. Esta é uma ameaça muito mais assustadora do que dez Dráculas e cem Lobisomens juntos.
Ao contrário da técnica que apresenta em sua trama, certamente será lembrado por muito tempo.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Em nenhum dos filmes de vingança produzidos recentemente a retórica eleitoreira e bélica de Bush tornou-se tão visível quanto em Poder de Fogo.
A grande força (do filme) reside na poderosa performance da jovem Sarah Polley.
O apelo universal da história narrada por Homero é o suficiente para que o filme mereça ser visto.
Surpreende o espectador, que, ao final da projeção, descobre que realmente se importou com aqueles personagens.
O roteiro apresenta diversos defeitos que provavelmente só foram agravados pelo fato de nada menos do que cinco roteiristas terem feito suas revisões particulares.
Por que contar a história de uma menina que se torna adulta se isto não será explorado pelo filme?
Sua fragilidade narrativa pouco significa frente à boa causa que representa. Além disso, é sempre divertido ver (nas telas) ondas gigantes cobrindo uma metrópole, não é mesmo?
Acerta em sua ambientação e na caracterização da dupla principal. Pena que falhe em todo o resto.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Street (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Sou contra a pena de morte, mas teria o maior prazer em ajudar a prender a protagonista deste filme na cadeira elétrica e dar o comando 'Roll on two!'.
Filmado apenas em locações, provoca um impacto ainda maior ao mostrar um país destruído pela guerra - evocando, neste sentido, o inesquecível Alemanha, Ano Zero.
Embora fique devendo o comentário social que transformou o filme original em um clássico, Madrugada dos Mortos é uma produção eficiente e divertida que merece aplausos.
É uma pena constatar que, afinal de contas, Meg Ryan tirou a roupa por um filme que, ironicamente, também se encontra despido. Neste caso, de méritos artísticos.
Stiller e Wilson certamente já provaram ser capazes de originarem uma franquia baseada não em personagens, mas em suas próprias personalidades.
