movie_title: An Episode in the Life of an Iron Picker (2013)

movie_review_blurb: This Doug Liman directed feature is a cut above the usual in terms of cerebral content, but it's still difficult to imagine it appearing on Mensa must-see lists any day soon.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The good news about this enjoyable piece is that they do manage to raise a few laughs. McCarthy's knockabout schtick is bound to get old at some stage, but it hasn't happened yet, while Sarandon isn't found wanting in the comic smarts department.
I wouldn't say I hated it but my dislike knew no bounds.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's not going to change your life but Dracula fans will surely find it delivers decent fang, sorry bang for your buck.
If you can treat the experience as an extended bubble-bath and remember the whole affair is to depth and substance what Boyzone were to Bob Dylan, you won't go far wrong.
[Pitt] delivers an Oscar-worthy performance in the central role and while attempts to mix the populist and the profound don't always work, it remains a captivating piece.
A searing indictment of the current regime in Iran, this daring and brave piece deserves as wide an audience as possible.
Witherspoon is, dare I say it, foot-perfect in the central role while the exceptional cinematography effortlessly reflects the epic beauty of the American wilderness.
Though possibly lacking a little bang bang for your buck, A Most Violent Year represents an absorbing, thoughtful and successful attempt to subvert the usual grisly gangster-chic stereotypes.
Written and directed with admirable verve by Dean DeBlois, How to Train Your Dragon ticks all the important boxes required of top quality family-friendly animation.
Plot implausibilities and Knightley's comedic deficiencies, however, ensure that proceedings never move much beyond the passable.
Interstellar needs to be seen on the biggest screen you can get your eyes on for maximum impact.
12 Years a Slave? It feels much longer.
Like all great art, it's a journey into the heart of psychological darkness that sheds a luminous light.
The psychedelic second section derails the finished product somewhat but it's never less than absorbing. Cult classics have evolved from less.

Clocking in at close to three hours, Boyhood overstays its welcome a little; but strong performances, an evocative soundtrack together with the director's flair for off-the-cuff profundity ensure that fans of quality movie-making won't be disappointed.

Cooper excels in the central role while Eastwood succeeds in the difficult task of delivering a war movie that focuses more on the personal sacrifice made by soldiers than it does on politics. It's all the better for it.
Stenders has made an emotional, rolling thunder of a film, one this extraordinary band deserves.
This moving story is one that will stay with you long after you watch it -- and be prepared to cry.
Heartwrenchingly sad, yet ultimately uplifting, Shine director Hicks more than matches the film that made him famous with this deeply moving tale.

Year of the Dog succeeds in drawing you in, making you look at the world from her perspective. By the end of the movie, you will recognize what kind of a person she is -- and you'll understand how she came to be that way.
The movie is as disposable as the music in it. But movie theaters need filler, too -- and this is the best kind.
What Love Is overflows with mind-numbing patter, bizarrely delivered with the arch formality of David Mamet, with the net effect of being yelled at for no reason.

Why were they ... ? Did she ... ? Couldn't he have just ... ? Since I have no intention of watching the movie two more times to sort it all out, I'm left disgruntled. It's almost enough to make you lose faith in horror movies.
The prospect of change is complicated, but Diggers is also a reminder of the powerful simplicity of friendship.

Away From Her isn't just a portrait of Alzheimer's. For a generation that doesn't have a lot of marital role models, it's also a lyrical portrait of what it means to stick with a person for the long run. There are no easy answers.
My advice? Enter your own dream state, and surrender your brain.
Be warned: Dinosaurs is a little scary. Nothing tries to eat you, which is nice, but with the 3D effect, these ginormous creatures practically perch -- menacingly -- on your armrest.
Frivolous, and ultimately forgettable? Of course. But if this movie is about high school tolerance, then superficial teenagers deserve our compassion, too.
Caterina Scorsone plays Alice with a nice balance of determination, skepticism, and open-mindedness.
Everything about it is whompingly (whoopingly?) obvious, from the hit-you-over-the-head narration to the tidy ending.

[Hitchcock] has very shrewdly interwoven crime, sex and suspense, blended the real and the unreal in fascinating proportions and punctuated his film with several quick, grisly and unnerving surprises.
Sometimes it's nice to just relax and listen to the deep soothing tones of Anthony Hopkins, even if what he's saying is absolute dribble.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The rest of us can take heart in charming little comedies like The Reluctant Infidel that stress our commonalities and make our differences something to laugh about.
The film's climax delivers and delivers and just keeps topping itself, making it possibly the most satisfying experience since cheeseburgers after a very big night.
It loiters somewhere within the void of movie limbo, destined to be lost amongst all the other films where an interesting idea failed to translate onto the big screen.
Never heavy handed or melodramatic, [The Hedgehog] wisely allows the humour and drama on display to flow naturally and steadily.
The American is a character piece, and in this it succeeds terrifically.
GasLand [backs] up its agenda with a calm and comprehensive case of evidence that impassions, not bullies, the audience into action.
The Fighter is not an edgy movie, but it doesn't need to be. It [...] transfixes us with flesh and blood characters that never pull their punches.
The movie has Shyamalan all over it - and not in a good way.
Compared to quality animated alternatives such as Tangled and Megamind, Yogi is unBearable.
Sanctum is an accomplished survival thriller with a genuine emotional core that takes both character drama and visual spectacle seriously.
The drama is satisfying and the message is pertinent, making 5 Days of War a worthy alternative to all the mindlessness on offer this blockbuster season.
Horrible Bosses may not be ground-breaking comedy, but it *is* comedy.
An entertaining escapist fable.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If you cannot tolerate apartheid in the name of politics, this Madhur Bhandarkar scrapbook straight from the 70s is for you.

Just like any other female-centric film of recent times, Anarkali sets foot on the unexplored territories of revenge and redemption, only this time, she is both the damsel in distress and her knight in shining armour.
For anyone who feels burdened and bogged down by life, this light-hearted tale of uncertainty and survival is a definite watch.
movie_title: You Are My Sunday (Tu Hai Mera Sunday) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: All in all, Ribbon starts off with one storyline and ends with another, but fails to capture the gamut of both.
A well executed horror flick; gripping.
The intent is good and so are the actors in it. But, the script and direction, especially cinematography, is below average.
Despite having an element of pragmatism in the film, Union Leader crumbles towards the end because of poor execution, thus making it another run-of-the-mill movie about rich versus the poor.
While the glam quotient was in place, acting, direction and story clearly were not.
It is a story that tries to take on the system by bringing to light its wrongdoings, but drowns in its own mediocrity instead.
movie_title: Kuldip Patwal: I Didn't Do It! (2017)

movie_review_blurb: At two hours of runtime, this Shaadi feels like it won't ever get over!
True story of drugs and sex is for adults only.
Not all rainbows and hugs -- some scares, too.
Magic-filled fantasy adventure for tweens and up.
Great voice talents, but weak storyline and frankly not much groove.
Below-average movie pushes merchandise to kids.
movie_title: The Care Bears Movie II: A New Generation (1986)

movie_review_blurb: Superb acting on life's journey; not for kids.
The cast's talents alone can't save the film from its awkward tonal shift and a story that feels out of sync with the modern era that it's set in.

No one's lifeblood is at stake, but the movie's pitiful victims will find themselves out the price of a movie ticket and nearly two hours of their lives that they will never get back. And let's not forget the price of popcorn and parking.
Almodovar has taken the classic film noir and given it a new spin -- there are no gumshoes, no smoking gun, just one lone film director confronting humanity's black heart.
Condon once again proves himself to be a consummate ringmaster of thought provoking material, clever casting and spectacular performances by atypical leading men.
The film, like Barrie's play is a testament to the imagination and its amazing powers.
A genuine laugh riot.
What remains in the mind long after the film is over is an early, fevered sexual encounter between Linney and Grace's characters.
The word thriller also implies some sort of suspense, but every time Green comes close to creating any, he undercuts it by focusing on mundane aspects of the boys' journey.
This is a movie full of passion for the theater that zestfully captures the color of Ned Kynaston's times.
Induces many more unintentional giggles than it does gasps of anxiety or fear.
What Clancy needs to remember if he is ever given another shot at a feature is that what might work on TV often shrinks on the big screen.
There are plenty of laughs to be had in this.
A pearl of a movie -- maybe it's a little precious, but it's also luminous.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The film is moving and disturbing at the same time.
What's wonderful about Salles' film is that he captures the rhythm of the odyssey, the sense of adventure waiting around every corner, and he lets us all come along for the ride.
It's not that fun or that sexy.
This is not a horror film, but it is horrifying.
It's the Spruce Goose that provides an apt metaphor for this misfire of a movie: It's big and sleek, a thrilling engineering marvel, but it only ever briefly takes flight.
[The screenplay] never exactly brings these people to life.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A lot of credit for the power of The Woodsman has to go to Bacon for bringing out the full range of Walter's humanity, from his ugly impulses to his struggle to overcome them.
What could have been a funny and devastating portrait of a youth on the brink of adulthood instead devolves into not always convincing melodrama.
Kung Fu Hustle boasts not just audacious action, but tons of laughs, a likeable (in spite of himself) hero in the seemingly hapless Sing, and one kick-ass, foul-mouthed, and awe-inspiring Landlady.
Mostly, the movie seems to exist as an excuse to blow things up and rig massive stunts.
One of those purely delightful children's films that manages to be sweet without getting sticky and garner laughs without resorting to scatological humor.
A better question might be, why bother?
A disaster: well-meaning, but hopelessly trite, obvious, and condescending toward the very process it intends to celebrate.

Writer/director Mike Binder and his ensemble cast, headed by actress Joan Allen, prove that even the hoariest of set-ups can still produce excellent drama, providing the writing is sharp and the acting superior.
This just represents one more notch down on Willis' foundering career.
Where Maybury's direction is relentlessly stylish, screenwriter Massy Tadjedin's script sputters along from one unlikely scenario to the next.
The contemporary interviews, for the most part, are notable for their wit, but it's the historical record that makes Inside Deep Throat so fascinating.
Schultze may have the blues, but the film of his wanderings is a joyful experience.
Bring a watch. You'll be checking it often.
Here, comedy tries to compete with maudlin underpinnings, and eventually the movie drowns in a sea of soap.
This is one movie that's definitely dead on arrival.

Fun, violent, and featuring some great scenes of lumbering elephants, it isn't art, it isn't particularly skillful craft (outside of the fight scenes and RZA's aural contributions), but it's an awfully good time.

The film is being marketed as a horror thriller, but it lacks suspense and is never particularly scary. It's just weak, and the misogyny that has always animated LaBute's work is really tired. Man, give it a rest already.

Because it's basically sketch comedy, it suffers from that unevenness that comes from trying to string a bunch of sketches together to form a cohesive whole. It is also ribald, outrageous, shameless, and oddly warmhearted.
Alas, it never quite reaches that gaga level that would truly send it over the top, but this disaster flick is hardly disastrous.
The main problem with Queens is that the many parts never coalesce into a satisfying whole, the result, perhaps, of too many subplots and too many characters to fit comfortably in one small movie.
There is no edge to the movie at all, and that blandness will render it forgettable to anyone over the age of 12 or so, but for all that, it is pleasant enough, and occasionally even fun.
For all those defects, Pulse is entertaining enough, providing one wants nothing more than an undemanding diversion.
Conversations with Other Women is a small drama, but with the attention to character and emotionality, it plays on screen as something larger.
It's certainly a pleasant enough way to kill 90 minutes.
movie_title: Shock to the System: A Donald Strachey Mystery (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This is one film in which the CGI and other effects blend seamlessly into the production, and special kudos should go to production designer Claude Paré, whose job it was to create this fanciful rendition of the Museum of Natural History.
This unwieldy mix of action, romance, and politics collapses under the weight of its high-minded ambitions and questionable story.

Take the trouble to find this film. It's worth it, if only to reacquaint oneself with the magic that flowed from the pen of Beatrix Potter, or to once again experience the easy rapport between Zellweger and McGregor.
Into a season of Hollywood blockbusters, this import arrives with the impact of a high-velocity bullet.
movie_title: Triad Election (Hak se wui yi wo wai kwai) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cotillard is capable of taking something ordinary and transforming it into something special, and that is exactly what she does in La Vie En Rose.
If this is the final Ocean's movie, saving the best for last is a wonderful way to go out.
The movie is a missed opportunity. It has all the ingredients of a delightfully twisted, sleek little thriller. But with all that extra padding, Mr. Brooks is just one bloated mess.
As a drama, Angel-A does not rank as a great movie, but as an homage to Paris, it is sensational. For this viewer, at least, that is good enough.
The latest eye-popping and surreal anime from Satoshi Kon (Tokyo Godfathers).
It is the rare family film that never condescends and offers enough of a story to entertain both parent and child.
This is one of those superhero movies in which the superheroes are not nearly as charismatic as the villain. Luckily for this sequel, the Silver Surfer is on the scene.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The results are uneven, but with each segment focused on a different arrondissement and only about five minutes in length, one does not have to linger in any neighborhood -- good or bad -- for very long before its time to move on.
Why would anyone want to spend time with these characters in the first place?
The longing is palpable, for love and for just companionship. In this languorous world, the drama's title speaks volumes. No one wants to sleep alone.
movie_title: I Don't Want to Sleep Alone (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A brain-dead action movie. 28 Days Later director Danny Boyle and that movie's screenwriter Alex Garland serve as executive producers this time around and they should be ashamed of themselves for so blatantly selling out their original vision.
If Braff really wants a movie career, he is going to have to do better than this mediocrity. Why should anyone pay to see this when they can catch his act on TV for free?
This is one off-the-wall sex comedy. It is even occasionally actually funny in its offbeat fashion, but it is essentially stupid and the forays into sexual violence are downright ugly.
movie_title: The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Men presents a provocative proposition, because it is not all that far-fetched in our age of environmental degradation and the potential it has to wreak havoc. The film is also that rare thing, one that entertains even as it leaves you thinking.
If anyone ever had any doubt that great actors can elevate a movie, they need look no further than Snow Cake for the proof that they can.
Zoo, with its idiosyncratic subject matter, may not be the easiest sell in the world, but anyone interested in provocative, challenging, and unexpected fare owes it to themselves to check it out.

It is smart enough to captivate not just the women who loved the books as kids, but also the boys and men that would normally disdain such a 'chick' flick. That nice Nancy Drew just has a way of winning people over.
Stripped of much of the director's trademark deadpan humor and saddled with such an extremely passive protagonist, getting through the drama becomes an exercise in patience.
It is that rare romantic comedy in which women can actually see themselves.
Hathaway and McAvoy are appealing, but bland. The scenes that hark back to Pride and Prejudice are not so much evocative as hackneyed. It is all very pleasant, but it is also a bit of a bore.
The movie is never dull and like the best episodes of the series, it is frequently hilarious, rich in visual humor and verbal wit.
[Director] Meadows does such a find job creating the tiny universe that it seem hermetically sealed from the rest of England.
A valuable summary of a variety of missteps that have led to the current debacle.

The biggest problem with the movie isn't the actors or even the half-baked script; it is that it never successfully draws one into its world. Watching Goya's Ghosts, one begins to daydream about Michael Palin.
A mess with moments of transcendence, suggesting that [director] Lee has talent. But she needs to learn how to get out of her own way.
It does not aim high, yet it cannot even hit the low targets it sets for itself. It is simply painful.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: As might be expected in a film that stars two such heavyweights, Talk to Me is a master class in acting. Ejiofor and Cheadle are both terrific, investing their characters with more than just personality, but also with heart and soul.

Lady Chatterley is nearly three hours long, a punishing length for such a lethargic film. Julien Hirsch's cinematography and Constance's beloved woods are gorgeous, but pretty pictures are not enough when the drama is so inert.
It is just too bad that the location is far more evocative than the drama itself.
An exuberant, if cautionary, tale of love and plastic surgery.
A high-octane symphony of machine battling machine and stuff blowing to pieces.
A scrumptious and savory entrée, delivered with wit and aplomb. It is the most delicious offering yet from those wizards at Pixar.
This is action at its most entertaining and proof that there is a lot of life left in this franchise.
A handsome film, but no amount of superior art direction or glittering surface can obscure the rigor mortis that engulfs the drama.

Next is tasty, but only in an empty-calorie sort of way.
